ASSESSMENT: Mr. Almanzar is a 29-year-old male presenting with erectile dysfunction and premature ejaculation. His young age and medical history suggest primarily psychogenic erectile dysfunction, though additional factors including his anxiety disorder and medication side effects (particularly from previous psychiatric medications) may be contributing. His premature ejaculation began in 2021 and persists despite low-dose SSRI treatment. He has no evidence of hypogonadism based on physical exam, no concerning urologic symptoms, and no signs of vascular disease based on normal lipid profile and absence of diabetes.


Problem #1: Erectile Dysfunction (N52.9)
- Young patient with likely psychogenic erectile dysfunction
- No physical examination findings suggestive of hypogonadism
- Contributing factors may include anxiety disorder and medication effects
- No evidence of vascular disease (normal lipids, no diabetes)

Problem #2: Premature Ejaculation (F52.4)
- Onset in 2021
- Current treatment with low-dose escitalopram with suboptimal response
- No anatomical abnormalities noted on exam

Problem #3: Anxiety Disorder (F41.9)
- May be contributing to sexual dysfunction
- Currently followed by Mental Health
- On escitalopram 5mg (half tablet) daily


PLAN:

1. Erectile Dysfunction:
   - Recommend trial of PDE5 inhibitor: Sildenafil 50mg, 1 tablet PRN for sexual activity, not to exceed 1 dose per day
   - Counseled patient on proper use, potential side effects, and contraindications with nitrates
   - Behavioral recommendations: stress reduction, communication with partner, and avoiding excessive alcohol

2. Premature Ejaculation:
   - Continue escitalopram at current dose if no concerning side effects
   - Behavioral techniques: stop-start technique, squeeze technique, and deep breathing exercises
   - Topical anesthetic options discussed as alternative: lidocaine/prilocaine cream PRN

3. Labs:
   - Order morning total testosterone, free testosterone, LH, FSH, and prolactin to rule out hormonal causes of erectile dysfunction
   - Complete metabolic panel and lipid profile in 3 months

4. Follow-up:
   - Return to clinic in 3 months to assess response to therapy
   - Sooner if side effects from medication occur or symptoms worsen
   - Consider sex therapy referral if insufficient improvement

5. Provided patient education materials on erectile dysfunction and premature ejaculation.

Patient verbalized understanding of treatment plan, medication instructions, and potential side effects. All questions were answered.

/es/ Dr. Rodriguez
Urologist

# VA UROLOGY CLINIC NOTE

DATE: July 7, 2025

ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Rodriguez

CC: Follow-up of elevated PSA

HPI: Mr. Donald Cruse is a 65-year-old male who returns today for follow-up evaluation of significantly elevated PSA. He was initially seen on 5/5/2025 for evaluation of rising PSA from 1.32 ng/mL in 2017 to 12.21 ng/mL in February 2025. His most recent PSA was 12.21 ng/mL with a very low free PSA percentage (3.29%), concerning for clinically significant prostate cancer. The patient has a family history of prostate cancer (father). Since his last visit, the patient underwent prostate MRI and is now returning to discuss results and further management. He has completed alcohol rehabilitation recently and remains sober. He continues to report minimal lower urinary tract symptoms with mild nocturia.


+---------------+------+
|        IPSS          |
+---------------+------+
| Symptom       | 7/7  |
+---------------+------+
| Empty         |  1   |
| Frequency     |  2   |
| Urgency       |  2   |

| Intermittency |  0   |
| Flow          |  2   |
| Nocturia      |  3   |
+---------------+------+
| Total         |10/35 |
| BI            | 3/6  |
+---------------+------+

DIETARY HISTORY: Coffee-4 cups every morning. No soda. Tea- not usually. ETOH- recently quit. Spicy foods-occasionally, 3 times a week.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Service-connected veteran (100%). Not Agent Orange exposed. No tobacco use in 40 years. History of alcohol dependence, recently completed rehabilitation and currently abstinent since April 2025. History of exposure to potentially hazardous substances during military service.

FAMILY HISTORY: Father died of prostate cancer at age 83. No other family members with prostate cancer. No other significant cancer family history.

SEXUAL HISTORY: History of erectile dysfunction, managed with sildenafil 100mg as needed.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- Hypertensive heart disease
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- Hyperlipidemia
- Obstructive sleep apnea
- Chronic post-traumatic stress disorder
- Recurrent major depressive disorder
- Alcohol dependence (in recovery)
- Gout
- Low back pain
- Cervicalgia
- Steatosis of liver
- Tachycardia
- Seizure disorder under evaluation

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: No major surgical history documented.

PSA CURVE:
[r] Feb 28, 2025 1125    12.21H
[r] Aug 13, 2024 1208    11.63H
[r] Jul 19, 2024 1030    14.68H
[r] Nov 29, 2023 0950    10.67H

[r] Oct 01, 2021 1010    3.91
[r] Oct 09, 2020 1050    2.70
[r] Jun 14, 2019 1128    1.96
[r] Aug 04, 2017 0911    1.32

PATHOLOGY RESULTS:
Pending prostate biopsy.

MEDICATIONS:
- Atorvastatin calcium 80mg daily at bedtime
- Carboxymethylcellulose 0.5% ophthalmic solution
- Olopatadine HCL 0.1% ophthalmic solution
- Ferrous gluconate 324-325mg daily
- Folic acid 1mg daily
- Gabapentin 600mg three times daily
- Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily
- Losartan 100mg daily
- Metformin HCL 500mg twice daily
- Methocarbamol 750mg twice daily as needed
- Metoprolol succinate 100mg one and half tablets daily
- Prazosin HCL 1mg at bedtime (caution with sildenafil)
- Quetiapine fumarate 50mg at bedtime
- Renal multivitamin daily
- Sertraline HCL 200mg daily
- Thiamine 100mg daily
- Sildenafil citrate 100mg as needed for ED
- Empagliflozin 10mg daily
- TRUE METRIX glucose monitoring supplies

ALLERGIES: No known allergies.

=========================================ENDOCRINE LABS =============================
Hemoglobin A1c: 7.9% (May 21, 2025) - High

========================================= LABS =====================================
PSA: 12.21 ng/mL (Feb 28, 2025) with free PSA 0.40 ng/mL (3.29% free)
CBC: Mild anemia with Hgb 12.5 g/dL (May 21, 2025)
Iron studies (June 4, 2025): Iron sat 18.0% (low), consistent with iron deficiency
PT/INR: PT 14.5 sec (slightly prolonged), INR 1.2 (May 5, 2025)
BNP: 10 pg/mL (normal, June 4, 2025)

========================================= IMAGING ==================================
Prostate MRI: (June 2, 2025)
Findings: 1.7 cm lesion in the right mid peripheral zone demonstrating restricted diffusion and early enhancement, PI-RADS 4, highly suspicious for clinically significant prostate cancer. No evidence of extraprostatic extension or seminal vesicle invasion. No significant lymphadenopathy. No bone lesions.
====================================================================================
GENERAL ROS:
Gen: Independent ADL's, No fever, chills, weight loss
EENT: No recent visual changes, no stiff neck or limited range of motion
Derm: No abnormal or changing skin lesions. 
CV: No chest pain at rest; No palpitations, No syncope, No claudication, No PND; No easy bleeding or bruising
RESP: No report of dyspnea or SOB at rest
GI: No diarrhea, nausea, vomiting 
GU: See HPI
MSK: no myalgias or new bone pain 
Neuro: No headache, syncope, dizziness.
Psych: No depression or anxiety. 
 
 
PHYSICAL EXAM:

 
GENERAL: Well-developed, well-nourished gentleman with appropriate 
orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
HEENT: Normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to 
palpation
CHEST: Normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. 
No palpable hernias.
GU: No CVAT, or bladder tenderness/fullness.
RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or 
rectal masses.
PROSTATE: Approximately 40 grams, smooth, firm, with a palpable nodule in the right mid peripheral zone.
CNS: Grossly intact motor function and sensation.


ASSESSMENT: Mr. Cruse is a 65-year-old male with significantly elevated PSA (12.21 ng/mL) showing concerning upward trajectory and very low free PSA percentage (3.29%). MRI has now demonstrated a 1.7 cm PI-RADS 4 lesion in the right mid peripheral zone, highly suspicious for clinically significant prostate cancer. Clinical exam correlates with a palpable nodule in the right lobe of the prostate. Given his age and otherwise reasonable medical condition, despite multiple comorbidities, he is an appropriate candidate for prostate biopsy for definitive diagnosis and consideration of curative treatment options if cancer is confirmed.


Problem #1: Elevated PSA with suspicious prostate MRI findings (PI-RADS 4)
Problem #2: Erectile dysfunction managed with sildenafil
Problem #3: Multiple comorbidities including hypertension, diabetes, depression, and alcohol dependence (in recovery)


PLAN:

1. Proceed with MRI-ultrasound fusion targeted prostate biopsy with systematic cores. Biopsy scheduled for 7/20/2025. Provided detailed pre-biopsy instructions including:
   - Continue prophylactic antibiotics as previously prescribed (ciprofloxacin 500mg)
   - Fleet enema on morning of procedure
   - Hold NSAIDs for 5 days before procedure
   - Continue prazosin but avoid sildenafil for 3 days before and after procedure

2. Discussed potential biopsy complications including bleeding, infection, urinary retention, and discomfort. Patient verbalized understanding of risks and benefits.

3. Discussed potential management options if prostate cancer is confirmed, including active surveillance, radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy options, and other treatments based on final pathology and staging.

4. Ordered pre-biopsy labs one week before procedure: CBC, PT/INR, CMP, and urine culture.

5. Continue current medical management of erectile dysfunction with sildenafil (hold for biopsy period as noted).

6. Follow up in clinic 7 days after biopsy to review pathology results and discuss next steps in management.

7. Provided educational materials regarding prostate cancer diagnosis, staging, and treatment options.

8. Encouraged continued abstinence from alcohol as part of overall health maintenance.

Ronald Rodriguez, MD
Urology

 related to various patterns of thinking.

 ASSESSMENT: 65-year-old male with significantly elevated PSA of 12.21 ng/mL 
 showing concerning upward trajectory from 1.32 ng/mL in 2017, with very low free 
 PSA percentage of 3.29%, indicating high risk for prostate cancer. Despite 
 normal DRE, the combination of PSA velocity and low free PSA percentage is 
 concerning for clinically significant prostate cancer. Patient has minimal lower 
 urinary tract symptoms with IPSS score of 1/35. Given his age and overall health 
 status, further diagnostic evaluation with prostate biopsy is warranted to rule 
 out prostate cancer.
 
 Problem #1: Elevated PSA 
 
 Problem #2: Erectile dysfunction, managed with sildenafil
 
 Problem #3: Multiple medical comorbidities including hypertension, diabetes, 
 hyperlipidemia
 
 PLAN:
 
 1. Prostate MRI prior to transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to better 
 characterize any suspicious lesions and guide targeted sampling. Will order 
 prostate MRI without and with contrast.
 
 2. Discussed risks, benefits and alternatives of prostate biopsy with patient. 
 Patient to take prophylactic antibiotics prior to biopsy per protocol 
 (ciprofloxacin 500mg PO), perform Fleet enema morning of procedure, and hold 
 anticoagulants/antiplatelet medications as appropriate.  Biopsy will be 
 scheduled once we know the results of the MRI.
 
 3. Laboratory testing prior to biopsy: PT/INR, CMP, CBC with platelets, and 
 urine culture.
 
 4. Continue current medical management of other conditions including sildenafil 
 for erectile dysfunction.
 
 5. Counsel patient on treatment options should biopsy confirm prostate cancer, 
 including active surveillance, radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, and 
 other options based on final pathology and staging.
 
 6. Follow up in clinic in 2 months to review biopsy results and discuss next 
 steps.
 
 7. Provide patient with educational materials regarding PSA screening, prostate 
 biopsy, and management options for potential prostate cancer.

 No further episodes of passing out. 
 Pt has episodes of strong, burning smell that last 10-15 minutes up to an hour. 
 These occur 2 to 3 times per week. No convulsions. Completed 28-day sobriety

 Pt has had painful tingling in feet. Describes neuropathy pain worsening pain in

 EEG routine 3/13/25: normal
 
 Neurology consult HPI (2/20/25):
 Pt is 65 yo m with PTSD, MDD, DM2, HTN, severe alcohol use disorder who presents 
 to neurology clinic for evaluation of episode of passing out and to evaluate for 
 possible seizure. Pt wife assists with history taking. In November 2024, he had 
 gone to the bathroom during the night and lost consciousness, falling to the 
 floor. His wife heard sound and woke to find him on the floor. She rouses him 
 physically within a minute and he came back to himself quickly. Pt denies any 
 preceding visual dimming, lightheadedness, nausea, diaphoresis, palpitations or 
 other neurologic symptom. Another episode, his wife was roused by family dog and 
 saw that her husband was lying in bed, eyes open, but couldn't talk. His speech 
 was gurgling. Pt remembers being aware of trying to talk but nothing could come 
 out. Within a few minutes, he was able to talk and walk, came back to himself. 
 Paramedics were called and evaluated pt who had returned to baseline. Pt 
 declined evaluation at ED. 
 
 Pt has had 3-4 episodes in which he smelt burning rubber that no one else could 
 smell lasting 5 minutes. The most recent episode was a few months ago. No dejavu 
 or jamais vu. No episodes of intense emotion. No visual symptoms. No convulsions 
 or previous seizure of any type. 
 
 
 Pt has had episodes of heart racing. Per chart review, has had evaluation with 
 EKG showing sinus tachycardia, NM stress test with no ischemia. Pt takes 
 metoprolol 150 mg PRN for episodes of heart racing. States he does not take 
 often. No other autonomic symptoms.
 
 Seizure risk factors: No TBI, CNS infection, febrile seizure. 
 No family hx of seizure.

 Assessment: 
 Pt is 65 yo m with PTSD, MDD, DM2, HTN, chronic back pain, severe alcohol use 
 disorder who presents to neurology clinic for evaluation of episode of passing 
 out and to evaluate for possible seizure. Pt has had isolated episode of likely 
 syncope though previous episode of altered awareness as well as 3-4 possible 
 olfactory seizures. Pt is recently sober and no further episodes of passing 
 out/altered awareness. Has had weekly olfactory sensations. Normal routine EEG 
 which does not completely rule out seizure. Pending MRI brain imaging. Given 
 episodes are transient sensory phenomenom with intact awareness, defer starting 
 ASM pending further workup. 
 
 Pt also endorsed painful paresthesias in feet with symmetric diminished 
 vibration sensation and diminished reflexes. Likely polyneuropathy 2/2 alcohol 
 use +/- diabetes. Will screen for other etiologies. Defer EMG/NCS at this time 
 given would not change management and etiology likely etoh/dm2. 
 
 Plan:
 - MRI brain w/wo with seizure protocol
 - defer ASM at this time and continue to monitor clinically
 - keep log of further events in question
 - neuropathy labs for thoroughness including B12, B1
 - start taking gabapentin 600 mg TID for neuropathy (currently for alcoholism 
 BID)
 - RTC in about 3 months after MRI completed

 ASSESSMENT: Mr. Dimuccio is a 70-year-old male with moderate lower urinary tract 
 symptoms due to BPH, currently managed with tamsulosin and tadalafil with 
 partial response. He has a concerning rise in PSA from 3.29 ng/mL to 4.62 ng/mL 
 over one year, representing a PSA velocity of 1.33 ng/mL/year, which exceeds the 
 0.75 ng/mL/year threshold of concern. Digital rectal examination today showed a 
 moderately enlarged, smooth prostate without palpable nodules. Given his rising 
 PSA despite 5-alpha reductase inhibitor treatment and moderate to severe LUTS 
 with bother index of 4/6, further evaluation including possible prostate biopsy 
 is warranted to rule out prostate cancer.
 
 Problem #1: Elevated PSA with concerning velocity (4.62 ng/mL, increased from 
 3.29 ng/mL over 1 year).  The Velocity may be a manifestation of his TRT, which 
 started at that time and is at a relatively high dose.
 
 Problem #2: Severe lower urinary tract symptoms due to BPH will reassess after 
 cancer screen workup
 
 Problem #3: Chronic kidney disease stage G3a (eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73m?)
 
 Problem #4:  ED.  The Tadalafil didn't work.  Will try Sildenafil, and VED. 
 
 PLAN:
 
 1. MRI Prostate WOW contrast.  Last one was 2 years ago
 
 2.  If MRI shows a lesion, then UroNav transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate 
 biopsy to evaluate rising PSA. 
 
 3. Continue current BPH medications (tamsulosin 0.8mg nightly). Consider adding 
 finasteride 5mg daily if workup is negative for malignancy.
 
 3. Review testosterone supplementation with patient's primary care provider as 
 this may potentially stimulate prostate growth. Consider discontinuation until 
 workup is complete.
 
 4. Schedule 1-2-month follow-up appointment to review results of the MRI, check 
 PSA after stopping TRT and make decision regarding prostate biopsy.
 
 5. Patient counseled on biopsy procedure, risks including bleeding, infection, 
 and pain. Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed with 
 recommended plan.
 
 6. Patient encouraged to continue smoking cessation efforts as this may benefit 
 urinary symptoms as well as overall health.

    *** TOBACCO TREATMENT PLAN NOTE Has ADDENDA ***
 
 Spoke with Veteran by telephone for purpose of tobacco cessation treatment
 planning/counseling.
 Length of call: 25 minutes 
 
 Type of tobacco use:   Vaping/e-cigarette 
 
 Amount: very frequently throughout the day 18% nicotine concentration. Even 
 keeps vape on bedside table and will use if wakes up in the night.
 Veteran does vape within 30 minutes of waking 
 
 History of tobacco use:
 Started smoking cigarettes in 7th grade, switched to dipping snuff in high 
 school. Used snuff until 1987, states it was very difficult to quit but he was 
 successful. Smoked a pipe for a while until son was a toddler and started 
 imitating him. Never smoked in the house. Resumed smoking cigarettes when 
 deployed, switched to vaping in 2010. Has used various strengths of nicotine 
 liquid in the vape, even as high as 33% when it was available. Now vaping 18% 
 liquid very frequently throughout the day and night.
 
 Stated reason or motivation for change: has quit many times on own with no 
 treatment. States this time he wants to quit "forever." Feels his addiction to 
 nicotine is quite high.
 
 Prior treatment/medications:   Nicotine patches, Nicotine gum; has quit on own 
 with no treatment many times. 
 
 Response to treatment (optional): patches were helpful when hospitalized last 
 year. nicotine gum could not tolerate the taste. Resumed vaping upon discharge.
 
 Discussed treatment options, including nicotine replacement therapy or other
 medication, behavioral counseling group, and/or telephone counseling.
 Strongly opposed to oral medication for tobacco cessation, concerns about side 
 effects and other ingredients within medications. Also states counseling would 
 not be helpful, knows that he would be "manipulative" and not benefit.
 
 Veteran is interested in:   Nicotine Replacement- patches definitely would like 
 to use, but open to trying lozenges also. Requests acupuncture. 
 
 MSE: Speech clear and coherent, mood euthymic. No evidence of elevated risk.
 
 Diagnosis: Nicotine Dependence, unspecified, severe
 
 Plan:
 
 ***Attention Primary Care Team: Veteran is requesting medication for
 tobacco cessation. Veteran expresses interest in the following options, if
 medically indicated:   Nicotine patches. Also open to adding Nicotine lozenge, 
 but primarily requesting patches. Per history, Veteran assessed to have high 
 level of nicotine dependence. Thank you very much for your review.  Please 
 advise if different coordination of care is needed.
 
 ***Veteran expresses interest in acupuncture for tobacco cessation. Already 
 connected with whole health program. Dr. Hahn, thank you for your review.
 
 
 Veteran provided with contact information and encouraged to contact with
 questions, concerns, or additional treatment needs. Tobacco Cessation Program
 can be reached at (210) 617-5300 x 16765

 ASSESSMENT: Mr. Dimuccio is a 70-year-old male with moderate lower urinary tract 
 symptoms due to BPH, currently managed with tamsulosin and tadalafil with 
 partial response. He has a concerning rise in PSA from 3.29 ng/mL to 4.62 ng/mL 
 over one year, representing a PSA velocity of 1.33 ng/mL/year, which exceeds the 
 0.75 ng/mL/year threshold of concern. Digital rectal examination today showed a 
 moderately enlarged, smooth prostate without palpable nodules. Given his rising 
 PSA despite 5-alpha reductase inhibitor treatment and moderate to severe LUTS 
 with bother index of 4/6, further evaluation including possible prostate biopsy 
 is warranted to rule out prostate cancer.
 
 Problem #1: Elevated PSA with concerning velocity (4.62 ng/mL, increased from 
 3.29 ng/mL over 1 year).  The Velocity may be a manifestation of his TRT, which 
 started at that time and is at a relatively high dose.
 
 Problem #2: Severe lower urinary tract symptoms due to BPH will reassess after 
 cancer screen workup
 
 Problem #3: Chronic kidney disease stage G3a (eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73m?)
 
 Problem #4:  ED.  The Tadalafil didn't work.  Will try Sildenafil, and VED.

 1. MRI Prostate WOW contrast.  Last one was 2 years ago
 
 2.  If MRI shows a lesion, then UroNav transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate 
 biopsy to evaluate rising PSA. 
 
 3. Continue current BPH medications (tamsulosin 0.8mg nightly). Consider adding 
 finasteride 5mg daily if workup is negative for malignancy.
 
 3. Review testosterone supplementation with patient's primary care provider as 
 this may potentially stimulate prostate growth. Consider discontinuation until 
 workup is complete.
 
 4. Schedule 1-2-month follow-up appointment to review results of the MRI, check 
 PSA after stopping TRT and make decision regarding prostate biopsy.
 
 5. Patient counseled on biopsy procedure, risks including bleeding, infection, 
 and pain. Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed with 
 recommended plan.
 
 6. Patient encouraged to continue smoking cessation efforts as this may benefit 
 urinary symptoms as well as overall health.

    *** TOBACCO TREATMENT PLAN NOTE Has ADDENDA ***
 
 Spoke with Veteran by telephone for purpose of tobacco cessation treatment
 planning/counseling.
 Length of call: 25 minutes 
 
 Type of tobacco use:   Vaping/e-cigarette 
 
 Amount: very frequently throughout the day 18% nicotine concentration. Even 
 keeps vape on bedside table and will use if wakes up in the night.
 Veteran does vape within 30 minutes of waking 
 
 History of tobacco use:
 Started smoking cigarettes in 7th grade, switched to dipping snuff in high 
 school. Used snuff until 1987, states it was very difficult to quit but he was 
 successful. Smoked a pipe for a while until son was a toddler and started 
 imitating him. Never smoked in the house. Resumed smoking cigarettes when 
 deployed, switched to vaping in 2010. Has used various strengths of nicotine 
 liquid in the vape, even as high as 33% when it was available. Now vaping 18% 
 liquid very frequently throughout the day and night.
 
 Stated reason or motivation for change: has quit many times on own with no 
 treatment. States this time he wants to quit "forever." Feels his addiction to 
 nicotine is quite high.
 
 Prior treatment/medications:   Nicotine patches, Nicotine gum; has quit on own 
 with no treatment many times. 
 
 Response to treatment (optional): patches were helpful when hospitalized last 
 year. nicotine gum could not tolerate the taste. Resumed vaping upon discharge.
 
 Discussed treatment options, including nicotine replacement therapy or other
 medication, behavioral counseling group, and/or telephone counseling.
 Strongly opposed to oral medication for tobacco cessation, concerns about side 
 effects and other ingredients within medications. Also states counseling would 
 not be helpful, knows that he would be "manipulative" and not benefit.
 
 Veteran is interested in:   Nicotine Replacement- patches definitely would like 
 to use, but open to trying lozenges also. Requests acupuncture. 
 
 MSE: Speech clear and coherent, mood euthymic. No evidence of elevated risk.
 
 Diagnosis: Nicotine Dependence, unspecified, severe
 
 Plan:
 
 ***Attention Primary Care Team: Veteran is requesting medication for
 tobacco cessation. Veteran expresses interest in the following options, if
 medically indicated:   Nicotine patches. Also open to adding Nicotine lozenge, 
 but primarily requesting patches. Per history, Veteran assessed to have high 
 level of nicotine dependence. Thank you very much for your review.  Please 
 advise if different coordination of care is needed.
 
 ***Veteran expresses interest in acupuncture for tobacco cessation. Already 
 connected with whole health program. Dr. Hahn, thank you for your review.
 
 
 Veteran provided with contact information and encouraged to contact with
 questions, concerns, or additional treatment needs. Tobacco Cessation Program
 can be reached at (210) 617-5300 x 16765

 moderately enlarged, smooth prostate without palpable nodules. Given his rising 
 PSA despite 5-alpha reductase inhibitor treatment and moderate to severe LUTS

  LOCAL TITLE: TOBACCO TREATMENT PLAN NOTE                        
 STANDARD TITLE: PSYCHOLOGY NOTE                                 
 DATE OF NOTE: MAR 19, 2025@13:02     ENTRY DATE: MAR 19, 2025@13:03:06      
       AUTHOR: CLEMENTS-THOMPSON,M  EXP COSIGNER:                           
      URGENCY:                            STATUS: COMPLETED                     
    *** TOBACCO TREATMENT PLAN NOTE Has ADDENDA ***
 Spoke with Veteran by telephone for purpose of tobacco cessation treatment
 planning/counseling.
 Length of call: 25 minutes 
 Type of tobacco use:   Vaping/e-cigarette 
 Amount: very frequently throughout the day 18% nicotine concentration. Even 
 keeps vape on bedside table and will use if wakes up in the night.
 Veteran does vape within 30 minutes of waking 
 History of tobacco use:
 Started smoking cigarettes in 7th grade, switched to dipping snuff in high 
 school. Used snuff until 1987, states it was very difficult to quit but he was 
 successful. Smoked a pipe for a while until son was a toddler and started 
 imitating him. Never smoked in the house. Resumed smoking cigarettes when 
 deployed, switched to vaping in 2010. Has used various strengths of nicotine 
 liquid in the vape, even as high as 33% when it was available. Now vaping 18% 
 liquid very frequently throughout the day and night.
 Stated reason or motivation for change: has quit many times on own with no 
 treatment. States this time he wants to quit "forever." Feels his addiction to 
 nicotine is quite high.
 Prior treatment/medications:   Nicotine patches, Nicotine gum; has quit on own 
 with no treatment many times. 
 Response to treatment (optional): patches were helpful when hospitalized last 
 year. nicotine gum could not tolerate the taste. Resumed vaping upon discharge.
 Discussed treatment options, including nicotine replacement therapy or other
 medication, behavioral counseling group, and/or telephone counseling.
 Strongly opposed to oral medication for tobacco cessation, concerns about side 
 effects and other ingredients within medications. Also states counseling would 
 not be helpful, knows that he would be "manipulative" and not benefit.
 Veteran is interested in:   Nicotine Replacement- patches definitely would like 
 to use, but open to trying lozenges also. Requests acupuncture. 
 MSE: Speech clear and coherent, mood euthymic. No evidence of elevated risk.
 Diagnosis: Nicotine Dependence, unspecified, severe
 Plan:
 ***Attention Primary Care Team: Veteran is requesting medication for
 tobacco cessation. Veteran expresses interest in the following options, if
 medically indicated:   Nicotine patches. Also open to adding Nicotine lozenge, 
 but primarily requesting patches. Per history, Veteran assessed to have high 
 level of nicotine dependence. Thank you very much for your review.  Please 
 advise if different coordination of care is needed.
 ***Veteran expresses interest in acupuncture for tobacco cessation. Already 
 connected with whole health program. Dr. Hahn, thank you for your review.
 Veteran provided with contact information and encouraged to contact with
 questions, concerns, or additional treatment needs. Tobacco Cessation Program
 can be reached at (210) 617-5300 x 16765
 /es/ Michele Clements-Thompson, Ph.D.
 Clinical Health Psychologist

ASSESSMENT: Mr. Williams is a 73-year-old African-American male with stable right renal Bosniak IIF cyst with enhancing septation measuring 3.6 cm on recent MRI from June 2025, showing no significant change from the previous MRI in May 2023. This represents a stable finding after prior concern about growth rate. He also has mild-moderate BPH symptoms well-controlled on alfuzosin with minimal LUTS (IPSS 3/35). His adrenal nodule remains stable at 1.2 cm and has been stable since 2015. Laboratory studies show stable renal function with eGFR of 71 mL/min and a PSA of 0.82 ng/mL, which is within normal range and consistent with his historical values.

Problem #1: Bosniak IIF right renal cyst
3.6 cm right renal cyst with enhancing septation, stable on recent MRI from June 2025 compared to May 2023. This is reassuring as previous concerns about growth rate appear to have stabilized. Given stability over multiple years of imaging, continued surveillance is appropriate.

Problem #2: BPH with LUTS
Symptoms remain well-controlled on alfuzosin with IPSS score of 3/35, similar to previous visits. No urinary retention. Patient continues to practice good fluid management habits. Ejaculatory dysfunction likely related to alpha-blocker therapy but patient is accepting of this side effect given the good control of urinary symptoms.

Problem #3: Right adrenal nodule
1.2 cm nodule stable since 2015. Previously ordered biochemical workup results for metanephrines are still pending, but given the long-term stability of this nodule and no concerning radiologic features, this is most likely a benign adenoma.

PLAN:
1. Continue alfuzosin 10 mg nightly for BPH (refilled)
2. Continue surveillance of renal cyst with repeat imaging in 6 months; the stable appearance on recent MRI is reassuring
3. Check pending plasma metanephrine results; no further imaging needed for adrenal nodule given stability since 2015
4. Continue current voiding habits and fluid management
5. Return to clinic in 6 months with repeat labs including UA, BMP, and PSA
6. Discussed that ejaculatory dysfunction is likely related to alfuzosin, but given the good control of his urinary symptoms and his acceptance of this side effect, we will continue current management

# UROLOGY CLINIC NOTE

CC: Follow-up for prostate cancer, nephrolithiasis, and LUTS.

HPI:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of T1CNxMx Gleason 4+4=8 prostate adenocarcinoma diagnosed in August 2015. He underwent IMRT with neoadjuvant and concurrent ADT in 2015, with the last ADT dose in October 2016. His PSA has remained undetectable since treatment, with the most recent PSA on January 6, 2025, at 0.04 ng/mL. He has a history of radiation cystitis and recurrent nephrolithiasis.

The patient presents today for routine follow-up of prostate cancer and management of urinary symptoms. He recently completed a course of antibiotics for a urinary tract infection diagnosed on January 21, 2025, which showed Group B Streptococcus >100,000 col/mL. Prior to antibiotic treatment, he reported symptoms of dysuria and urinary urgency, which have since improved. A CT urogram on March 4, 2025, showed bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi with no evidence of urothelial lesions, though bladder evaluation was limited due to artifact.

The patient previously underwent cystoscopy on December 30, 2024, which showed no bladder lesions, moderate bladder trabeculation, and no evidence of obstruction. His urinary symptoms have improved significantly with trospium 20 mg twice daily, which was increased from once daily during his January visit.

- Status post IMRT and ADT completed in 2016
- PSA remains undetectable at 0.04 ng/mL, consistent with no evidence of disease (NED)
- No evidence of recurrence on physical examination

Problem #2: Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and recurrent UTI:
- Improved with trospium 20 mg twice daily
- Recent UTI treated with antibiotics, currently resolved
- Moderate bladder trabeculation noted on cystoscopy in December 2024
- IPSS score improved to 7/35 from previous values

Problem #3: Recurrent nephrolithiasis:
- Bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi on CT urogram March 2025
- No hydronephrosis
- History of calcium phosphate and oxalate stone formation
- Normal renal function

PLAN:
1. Prostate Cancer:
   - Continue PSA monitoring every 6 months per NCCN guidelines for high-risk prostate cancer in long-term follow-up
   - Next PSA check in January 2026

2. LUTS/UTI:
   - Continue trospium 20 mg twice daily
   - Monitor for recurrent UTI symptoms; consider urine culture if symptoms recur
   - Maintain good hydration to help prevent recurrent UTI

3. Nephrolithiasis:
   - Continue dietary modifications:
     a. Increase fluid intake to maintain urine output >2.5 L/day
     b. Sodium restriction
     c. Limit animal protein and purine intake
     d. Continue high-volume Crystal Light lemonade intake
   - Continue allopurinol 300 mg daily to help prevent stone formation
   - Consider repeat CT in 12 months if clinically indicated

4. Follow-Up:
   - Return to clinic in 6 months with PSA, urinalysis, and renal function tests
   - Continue with cardiology follow-up for management of cardiac issues and medication adjustments

GENERAL: Well-developed, well-nourished gentleman with appropriate orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
HEENT: Normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to palpation.
CHEST: Normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. No palpable hernias.
GU: No CVAT or bladder tenderness/fullness. Left scrotum enlarged with palpable hydrocele. Bedside ultrasound estimates hydrocele volume at approximately 160 cc.
RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or rectal masses.
PROSTATE: Mildly enlarged, smooth and benign.
CNS: Grossly intact motor function and sensation.

ASSESSMENT:
Mr. Spencer is a 64-year-old male with a history of bladder wall lesions demonstrating cystitis cystica and glandularis on two separate biopsies (2017 and 2020), without evidence of malignancy. He has no current hematuria or urinary symptoms beyond mild nocturia. His PSA remains stable and within normal limits. He has a recurrent left hydrocele that continues to slowly enlarge despite multiple aspirations. The patient also has primary male hypogonadism with borderline low testosterone and low free testosterone levels, which may warrant treatment if he develops symptoms. His multiple comorbidities, including CAD s/p CABG and history of DVT/PE requiring anticoagulation, complicate surgical management of his hydrocele.

Problem #1: History of cystitis cystica and glandularis
No current hematuria or symptoms suggesting recurrence. Last cystoscopy January 2021 and last CT urogram June 2017. Current UA negative for blood.

Problem #2: Recurrent left hydrocele
Left hydrocele continues to slowly recur after aspiration in June 2024. Current volume approximately 160 cc. Patient is interested in definitive hydrocelectomy if anticoagulation can be safely held.

Problem #3: Primary male hypogonadism
Laboratory tests confirm low free testosterone with normal total testosterone and high-normal gonadotropins, consistent with primary hypogonadism.

PLAN:

1. Given absence of hematuria and stable PSA, no immediate need for repeat cystoscopy. Will continue surveillance with annual PSA testing and urinalysis.

2. Will refer to cardiology for clearance regarding temporary discontinuation of rivaroxaban to allow for left hydrocelectomy. Target date for surgery in October 2025, pending clearance.

3. Primary hypogonadism: Patient currently minimally symptomatic. Will reassess at next visit for development of hypogonadal symptoms. If symptoms develop, will consider testosterone replacement therapy after discussing risks/benefits, particularly regarding history of bladder pathology.

4. Continue current medications. Patient tolerating all medications without side effects.

5. Laboratory monitoring: Repeat UA, comprehensive metabolic panel, and PSA in 6 months.

6. Follow-up appointment in 3 months to reassess hydrocele and discuss surgical planning pending cardiology clearance.

7. Encouraged continued healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and weight management.

 ASSESSMENT: 63-year-old gentleman with h/o hematuria on anticoagulation as well 
 as inflammation of the bladder leading to cystitis cystica and cystitis 
 glandularis, demonstrated on 2 separate biopsies.  He 
 also has a h/o a large hydrocele that required aspiration.  His last CT urogram 
 was on 6/2/2017.  His last cystoscopy was in Jan 2021.  His last UA was in Feb 
 2023 and it was dip negative for blood.
 Problem #1: Hematuria. This is not currently a problem
 Problem #2: h/o cystitis glandularis.  This is considered a 
 potentially premalignant lesion.  A follow-up cystoscopy would be reasonable 
 though it is hard to make that argument in the absence of any microhematuria. 
 I will continue to follow for microhematuria, and should it occur and we will 
 perform cystoscopy again.  We will also monitor symptoms as this may also be 
 an indication of recurrence of that condition.
 Problem #4: Recurrent hydrocele.  He has had this aspirated on 3 different 
 occasions, most recently 3 months ago.  I offered hydrocelectomy for him at that 
 time but he wanted to wait.  Today it is clearly enlarging.  He is fully 
 anticoagulated, which is the reason he did not undergo a full hydrocelectomy the 
 last time. 
 Problem #5:  Male hypogonadism.  Repeated on two occassions.  He is eligble for 
 TRT.  Will wait for now to pursue this as he is not particularly symptomatic.
 PLAN:
 Will consider formal hydrocelectomy later, particularly if he can come off of 
 anticoagulation,  Tentatively we are looking at October.
 Mild hypogonadism-completed and he has primary male hypogonadism.
 He is currently anticoagulated for a prior LLE DVT and PE, but was able to 
 come off of this for his CABG surgery, and his aspiration and should be able 
 to do this again for the hydrocelectomy.  He will need IMC clearance however, 
 given his prior h/o CAD, PE and DVT.  He looks however, reasonably fit.

 ***ASSESSMENT AND COMPREHENSIVE PLAN OF CARE*** 
 SPENCER,DWAYNE J is a 63 year old MALE patient presenting to clinic for 
 evaluation of chronic left wrist pain.  Physical exam, imaging, and patient 
 history suggestive of multiple pain generators present in constellation of 
 symptoms.  Suspect that greatest source of pain is due to SLAC deformity, SL 
 tearing and associated hypertrophic synovial tissue based on physical exam. 
 Discussed treatment options with patient including repeat corticosteroid 
 injection, physical therapy, and surgical intervention.  Following discussion of 
 available treatment options, patient ultimately opted to proceed with surgical 
 intervention given short-lived pain relief with previous corticosteroid 
 injection.  We will plan on scheduling patient for arthroscopic debridement of 
 wrist with possible SL repair.
 Please schedule patient for a Monday PASS appointment for arthroscopic 
 debridement of wrist and possible SL repair with Dr. Brady.
 Patient is in agreement with above plan, expressed understanding, all 
 questions and concerns were addressed. 
 Return precautions given to patient. 
 ************************************************************************
 I spent 30 minutes reviewing prior notes, past medical history,
 medications, labs, imaging, doing H&P, explaining findings to the
 patient and discussing Tx options.
 Return to Clinic: pending PASS appointment
 ************************************************************************
 Patient counseled on:Arthritis Treatment options:
 We discussed with the patient today treatment options for arthritis 
 including: Observation, activity modification, NSAIDs, Bracing, PT, weight 
 loss, steroid/viscosupplementation injections, and surgical procedures. 
 Patient understands that surgical treatment options are reserved for when 
 conservative measures fail. The patient must be in appropriate health to 
 undergo an elective procedure. We discuss the importance of maintaining 
 appropriate weight (BMI <40), Diabetes control (Hgb A1c <7.5 if diabetic), 
 Smoking cessation, and limiting any narcotic/opioid use to reduce the risks 
 of perioperative complications.
 Weight Loss:
 Discussed with the patient today of importance of weight loss regarding
 arthritic pain and eligible of elective surgery in the future. Weight loss 
 can be difficult to accomplish but can have a dramatic effect on joint pain 
 and overall health. Dietary changes combine with light exercise should be 
 used to target a BMI <35, especially if being considered for elective surgery 
 or joint replacement.
 Diabetes Control
 Tight blood sugar control and Hgb A1c (<7.5) is one of the most important
 factors in reducing perioperative complications especially infections.
 Strategies were discussed with the patient today and further discussion with
 their PCP was encouraged to improve their HgB Alc.
 I reviewed the patient's case with an orthopedic resident who agrees with my 
 plan.

 02/20/24
 GENERAL: well developed, well nourished, gentleman with appropriate 
 orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
 HEENT: normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to 
 palpation
 CHEST: normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
 ABDOMEN: soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. 
 No palpable hernias.
 GU: no CVAT, or bladder tenderness/ fullness. Left scrotum enlarged. US at 
 bedside showed 140 cc in the hydrocele that has recurred.
 RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or 
 rectal masses.
 PROSTATE: Mildly enlarged, but smooth and benign.
 CNS: grossly intact motor function and sensation.
 ASSESSMENT: 62-year-old gentleman with history of hematuria on 
 anticoagulation as well as inflammation of the bladder leading to cystitis 
 cystica and cystitis glandularis, demonstrated on 2 separate biopsies.  He 
 also has a history of a large hydrocele that required aspiration.  His last 
 CT urogram was on 6/2/2017.  His last cystoscopy was in Jan 2021.  His last 
 UA was in Feb 2023 and it was dip negative for blood.
 Problem #1: Hematuria. This is not currently a problem
 Problem #2: History of cystitis glandularis.  This is considered a 
 potentially premalignant lesion.  A follow-up cystoscopy would be reasonable 
 though it is hard to make that argument in the absence of any microhematuria. 
 I will continue to follow for microhematuria, and should it occur and we will 
 perform cystoscopy again.  We will also monitor symptoms as this may also be 
 an indication of recurrence of that condition.
 Problem #4: Recurrent hydrocele.  He has had this aspirated on 2 different 
 occasions, and at his last visit it was recurring again.  I offered 
 hydrocelectomy for him at that time but he wanted to wait.  Today it is 
 clearly enlarging.  He is fully anticoagulated, which is the reason he did 
 not undergo a full hydrocelectomy the last time.  His volume is 150 cc on the 
 bedside bladder scanner (may not be the most accurate).  It is significant to 
 me, but he says it is still much smaller than before.  He does want it 
 aspirated again however.
 Problem #5:  Male hypogonadism.  Need better workup.  It is borderline and 
 needs repeating with fractionated androgens.
 PLAN:
 Will consider formal hydrocelectomy later.  Right now he favors aspiration 
 again. 
 Mild hypogonadism-complete endocrine workup
 He is currently anticoagulated for a prior LLE DVT and PE, but was able to 
 come off of this for his CABG surgery, and his aspiration and should be able 
 to do this again for the hydrocelectomy.  He will need IMC clearance however, 
 given his prior h/o CAD, PE and DVT.  He looks however, reasonably fit. 
 Dr Shane indicated to me he was willing to do the hydrocelectomy, when the 
 patient is ready to proceed.
 Aspiration 90 days
 RTC to see me in 120 days

 GENERAL ROS:
 Gen: Independent ADL's , No fever, chills, wt loss
 EENT:  No recent visual changes, no stiff neck or limited range of motion
 Derm: No abnormal or changing skin lesions. 
 CV:  No chest pain at rest; No palpitations, No syncope, No 
 claudication, No PND;  No easy bleeding or bruising
 RESP:  No report of dyspnea or SOB at rest
 GI:  No diarrhea, nausea, vomiting 
 GU: See HPI
 MSK: no myalgias or new bone pain 
 Neuro: No headache, syncope, dizziness.
 Psych: No depression or anxiety. 
 PHYSICAL EXAM:
 11/06/23
 13:16
     T:   96.3 F (35.7 C)
     P:   69
     R:   18
     B/P: 143/84
     Wt:  255.00 lb (115.67 kg)
     Body Mass Index: 31*
     Pulse Oximetry: 99%
     Pain: 4
 GENERAL: well developed, well nourished, gentleman with appropriate 
 orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
 HEENT: normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to palpation
 CHEST: normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
 ABDOMEN: soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. 
 No palpable hernias.
 GU: no CVAT, or bladder tenderness/ fullness. Left scrotum enlarged. US at 
 bedside showed 140 cc in the hydrocele that has recurred.
 RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or 
 rectal masses.
 PROSTATE: Mildly enlarged, but smooth and benign.
 CNS: grossly intact motor function and sensation.
 ASSESSMENT: 62-year-old gentleman with history of hematuria on anticoagulation 
 as well as inflammation of the bladder leading to cystitis cystica and cystitis 
 glandularis, demonstrated on 2 separate biopsies.  He also has a history of a 
 large hydrocele that required aspiration more recently.  His last CT urogram was 
 on 6/2/2017.  His last cystoscopy was in Jan 2021.  His last UA was in April 
 2023 and it was dip negative for blood.
 Problem #1: Hematuria.  He has not hematuria for more than a year.  This is not 
 currently a problem
 Problem #2: History of cystitis glandularis.  This is considered a potentially 
 premalignant lesion.  A follow-up cystoscopy would be reasonable though it is 
 hard to make that argument in the absence of any microhematuria.
 problem #3:  Male hypogonadism.  Need better workup.  It is borderline and needs 
 repeating with fractionated androgens.
 PLAN:
 Mild hypogonadism-complete endocrine workup
 Return 3 months followup with UA full set of labs.
 He wants to proceed with a formal hydrocelectomy when the hydrocele returns to a 
 large enough size.  Actually, it is already large enough to consider this, 
 however, at its current rate of growth it will be over 300 cc in Jan.  He has 
 some things he wants to finish during the holidays and will be ready after that 
 to proceed with surgery likely in March.  He is also currently anticoagulated 
 for a prior LLE DVT and PE, but was able to come off of this for his CABG 
 surgery, and his aspiration and should be able to do this again for the 
 hydrocelectomy.  He will need IMC clearance however, given his prior h/o CAD, PE 
 and DVT.  He looks however, reasonably fit.

# VA UROLOGY CLINIC NOTE

**DATE: 07/07/2025**
**PROVIDER: Ronald Rodriguez, MD**

CC: 
Follow-up for bilateral renal masses, nephrolithiasis, and BPH with obstruction

HPI:
Mr. Castro is a 77-year-old Latin American male with a history of BPH with outflow obstruction, nephrolithiasis, and bilateral renal masses who presents for routine follow-up. Patient has been managed with dual therapy including finasteride and tamsulosin for his BPH. He has been under active surveillance for bilateral renal masses, with most recent imaging from May 2025 showing stable bilateral renal lesions measuring 0.8 cm concerning for renal cell carcinoma. The patient also has poorly controlled Type II diabetes with latest A1c of 9.9% as of May 2025. Patient has multiple comorbidities including orthostatic hypotension, chronic kidney disease stage 3B (eGFR 52-57), and sensorineural hearing loss. Recent CT from January 2025 showed bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi. Patient was recently admitted to the hospital in April due to severe maxillary sinusitis, and his diabetic control has worsened since that time.

Consumes 3-4 bottles of fluid per day, mainly water with occasional juices. Has been working with dietitian but continues to struggle with dietary adherence, particularly with carbohydrate counting due to memory issues. Currently on insulin therapy with poor compliance.

No alcohol, drug use, or smoking. Quit smoking in 2004. Rare beer consumption during hot weather. Lives with girlfriend, receives assistance from daughter and son who bring him food and watch out for him.

Noncontributory.

17. Lidocaine 5% patch: Apply 2 patches daily for pain
18. Finasteride 5mg: Take one tablet daily for enlarged prostate

20. Various incontinence supplies, eye drops, and topical medications

ALLERGIES:

=========================================ENDOCRINE LABS =============================
- Hemoglobin A1C: 9.9% (05/24/2025), previously 8.8% (01/25/2025)

========================================= LABS =====================================
- Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL (05/24/2025)
- eGFR: 57 mL/min/1.73 m² (05/24/2025)
- Urinalysis (05/24/2025): Protein 100 mg/dL, Glucose ≥1000 mg/dL
- Microalbumin/Creatinine Ratio: 417.7 μg/mg (05/24/2025) - Clinical albuminuria

24-hour urine stone risk profile (05/24/2025):
- Sodium urate: 3.77 H
- Low urine volume: 1.14 L/day (optimal >2.0 L/day)
- Ammonium: 13 L mEq/day (normal 14-62)

========================================= IMAGING ==================================
MRI (05/01/2025):
No change in bilateral enhancing renal observations (8 mm), suspicious for small renal cell carcinoma.

CT (01/08/2025):
1. Bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi 3-4 mm in the calyces of bilateral kidneys
2. Multiple exophytic renal cysts
3. A 1.1 cm exophytic lesion of the lower pole of left kidney with slightly higher attenuation, possibly representing hemorrhagic cyst, increased in size from prior CT
4. No urinary tract calculus or hydroureteronephrosis evident

====================================================================================
GENERAL ROS:
Gen: Independent ADL's, No fever, chills, weight loss
EENT: No recent visual changes, no stiff neck or limited range of motion
Derm: No abnormal or changing skin lesions. 
CV: No chest pain at rest; No palpitations, No syncope, No 
claudication, No PND; No easy bleeding or bruising
RESP: No report of dyspnea or SOB at rest
GI: No diarrhea, nausea, vomiting 
GU: See HPI
MSK: no myalgias or new bone pain 
Neuro: No headache, syncope, dizziness.
Psych: No depression or anxiety. 
 
 
PHYSICAL EXAM:

 
GENERAL: well developed, well nourished, gentleman with appropriate 
orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
HEENT: normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to 
palpation
CHEST: normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
ABDOMEN: soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. 
No palpable hernias.
GU: no CVAT, or bladder tenderness/fullness.
RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or 
rectal masses.
PROSTATE: Small, smooth, without nodules, status post TURP
CNS: grossly intact motor function and sensation.

PVR: 162 cc

ASSESSMENT:
Mr. Castro presents with stable bilateral small renal masses under active surveillance, chronic nephrolithiasis, and BPH with moderate LUTS despite prior TURP and current medical therapy. His urologic conditions are complicated by progressive chronic kidney disease with eGFR in the 52-57 range, likely related to his diabetic nephropathy and recurrent nephrolithiasis. His diabetes remains poorly controlled with A1c of 9.9%, and he demonstrates significant diabetic cystopathy with diminished bladder sensation contributing to his voiding symptoms. He has overflow incontinence requiring protective pads, and post-void residual is elevated at 162 cc, indicating incomplete bladder emptying.

Problem #1: Bilateral Renal Masses (0.8 cm)
- Stable on surveillance per MRI 5/1/2025
- Continue active surveillance given small size and multiple comorbidities including CKD
- Schedule next follow-up imaging in 6 months

Problem #2: Nephrolithiasis
- Stable nonobstructing bilateral renal calculi 
- 24-hour urine shows elevated sodium urate, low volume
- Encourage increased hydration to maintain urine output >2L/day
- Dietary modifications: low sodium, low purine

Problem #3: BPH with LUTS/Diabetic Cystopathy
- Moderate symptoms (IPSS 19/35) despite prior TURP and dual medical therapy
- Elevated PVR (162 cc) with diminished bladder sensation consistent with diabetic cystopathy
- Continue finasteride 5mg daily and tamsulosin 0.4mg twice daily
- Implement timed voiding schedule to address overflow incontinence

PLAN:
1. Continue active surveillance for bilateral renal masses with MRI in November 2025
2. Increase fluid intake to at least 2.5-3L daily to help prevent stone formation
3. Continue current BPH medical therapy with finasteride and tamsulosin
4. Implement timed voiding schedule every 3-4 hours regardless of sensation to prevent overflow incontinence
5. Recommend double voiding technique to improve bladder emptying
6. Continue using incontinence pads as needed for protection
7. Emphasize importance of better glycemic control - discussed potential consideration of insulin pump with primary care team
8. Follow up in 3 months with repeat renal function tests, urinalysis, and PSA
9. Consider referral to nephrology for management of diabetic nephropathy if renal function worsens
10. Coordinate care with endocrinology and primary care for optimization of diabetes management

     Clinical History:
       53yo male presents for evaluation  of burning sensation in his
       stomach for 2-3 months after being taken off of his PPI and
       placed on an H2, pt noted progressive symptoms approx 1 hour
       after he eats noted sharp stabbing pain t/o his abdomen, pt noted
       no associated N/V/D,  lastly pt concern for dyuria w/o frequency
       and or urgency 
 
     Report Status: Verified                   Date Reported: JAN 09, 2016
                                               Date Verified: JAN 09, 2016
     Verifier E-Sig:/ES/Virginia SCHREINER
 
     Report:
       EXAM: 
         CT Abdomen and Pelvis With Intravenous Contrast.  
        
       CLINICAL HISTORY: 
         53 years old, male; Pain; Other: R/O peptic ulcer (gastric or
       duodenal; Patient HX: 53yo male presents for evaluation of
       burning sensation in his stomach for. 2-3 months after being
       taken off of his ppi and placed on an h2, pt noted. Progressive
       symptoms approx 1 hour after he eats noted sharp stabbing pain.
       T/o his abdomen, pt; 
        
       TECHNIQUE: 
         Axial computed tomography images of the abdomen and pelvis with
       intravenous contrast.  
         Coronal and sagittal reformatted images were created and
       reviewed.  
        
       CONTRAST: 
         100 mL of optiray administered intravenously.  
        
       EXAM DATE/TIME: 
         Exam ordered 1/9/2016 10:19 AM 
        
       COMPARISON: 
         No relevant comparison studies available.  
        
       FINDINGS: 
         Lower thorax:  Mild bibasilar stranding and atelectasis.  Very
       small sliding hiatal hernia minimal distal esophageal wall
       thickening.  
        
        ABDOMEN: 
         Liver:  No acute findings.  No definite mass.  
         Gallbladder and bile ducts:  Grossly normal.  No radiodense
       stones or biliary ductal dilation.  
         Pancreas:  Grossly normal.  No ductal dilation.  No mass.  
         Spleen:  Grossly normal.  No splenomegaly.  
         Adrenals:  Grossly normal.  No mass.  
         Kidneys and ureters:  Grossly normal.  No hydronephrosis.  No
       solid mass.  
        
        PELVIS: 
         Bladder:  Mild inflammation along the anterior urinary bladder
       wall.  No urinary bladder stones.  
         Reproductive:  Mild prominence of the prostate.  
         Appendix:  Very small densities within the appendix which may
       represent appendicoliths versus a very small amount of dense
       ingested material within the appendix.  No signs of acute
       appendicitis.  
        
        ABDOMEN & PELVIS: 
         Stomach and bowel:  Relative prominence of some of the gastric
       wall without adjacent inflammation may reflect lack of distention
       rather than gastritis or other inflammatory process.  
         Fluid/Air:  No definite free air or drainable fluid collection. 
         Lymph nodes:   No enlarged lymph nodes.  
         Vasculature:  Nonaneurysmal abdominal aorta without evidence of
       dissection.  
         Bones: Spinal degenerative changes and mild straightening of
       the normal lumbar lordosis.  
        
       
 
     Impression:
            
         VERY SMALL SLIDING HIATAL HERNIA AND FINDINGS WHICH MAY REFLECT
       REFLUX ESOPHAGITIS.  
        NO DEFINITE EVIDENCE OF ACUTE GASTRITIS OR PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE.  
         OTHER FINDINGS AS DISCUSSED ABOVE.  
        
        
       Report Interpretation has been completed via TeleRadiology by
       VIRGINIA SCHREINER MD

# VA CLINIC NOTE 
**Date of Service:** July 21, 2025
**Provider:** Ronald Rodriguez, MD (Urology)

CC: 
Follow-up for right scrotal swelling and hydrocele.

HPI:
Bryan Keith Theis is a 57-year-old male veteran returning for follow-up of right scrotal swelling and hydrocele. He was initially seen in November 2024 for acute right scrotal swelling and discomfort that had persisted for several weeks. An ultrasound at that time revealed a moderate-sized right hydrocele with internal debris. He was diagnosed with clinical epididymitis and started on Cipro for 30 days. The antibiotics were not particularly helpful. The patient reports intermittent pain that is not as severe as before. Some days he does not have pain, but it is present about 75% of the time. The hydrocele itself seems to change in size from day to day but is always present. A follow-up scrotal ultrasound on January 14, 2025, showed a stable moderate-sized right hydrocele without acute findings. He denies fever, chills, worsening pain, or urinary symptoms. He has a history of essential thrombocytosis managed with Ruxolitinib, as well as cervical spondylosis and chronic low back pain that are being addressed by neurology and pain management.

+---------------+------+
|        IPSS          |
+---------------+------+
| Symptom       | 7/21/25|
+---------------+------+
| Empty         |  0   |
| Frequency     |  0   |
| Urgency       |  0   |
| Hesitancy     |  0   |
| Intermittency |  0   |
| Flow          |  0   |
| Nocturia      |  0   |
+---------------+------+
| Total         | 0/35 |
| BI            | 0/6  |
+---------------+------+

DIETARY HISTORY:
Coffee - several cups a day. ETOH - rarely. Smokes occasionally cigarettes or cigars.

SOCIAL HISTORY:
The patient is married and works in asset protection for Home Depot. He is a former smoker who quit in April 2023 with a 45 pack-year history. He consumes alcohol socially.

FAMILY HISTORY:
Father has a history of skin cancer and essential thrombocytosis (Jak2 mutation). No other significant family history of cancer or genetic conditions.

SEXUAL HISTORY:
History of male erectile disorder, currently managed with vardenafil.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Essential thrombocythemia with JAK2 mutation
2. Chronic low back pain
3. Osteoarthritis of the lumbar spine
4. Obstructive sleep apnea
5. Allergic rhinitis
6. Male erectile disorder
7. Cervical spondylosis and cervicalgia
8. Sensory neuropathy
9. Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
10. Pancreatic cyst (follow-up imaging recommended at 6-12 months to confirm stability)
11. Trigeminal neuralgia
12. Hyperlipidemia
13. Former smoker (quit April 2023)

normal in size and texture with normal epididymis and cord. The right testicle 
is of normal size with moderate hydrocele present, reduced in tenderness 
compared to previous examination. The right epididymis is minimally tender to 
palpation with only mild discomfort noted. The cord is no longer thickened. No 
palpable abnormalities of the testes themselves.
RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or 
rectal masses.
PROSTATE: Small, smooth, without nodules or induration.

ASSESSMENT: 
Mr. Theis shows continued improvement in his right scrotal pain though it does not appear the antibiotics helped much. His right hydrocele remains stable per ultrasound from January 2025, with reduced tenderness on examination today. The ultrasonographic finding of a scrotal pearl suggests prior torsion and thrombosis of the appendix testis or epididymis which has now resolved, explaining his gradual improvement in symptoms. His essential thrombocytosis is well-controlled on Ruxolitinib though his platelet count remains slightly elevated at 461. The hydrocele is moderate in size and causes some discomfort and activity limitations, but the patient is not ready to consider surgical intervention at this time.

Problem #1: 
Right hydrocele, stable, with improving symptoms

Problem #2: 
History of clinical epididymitis, likely resolved appendix testis/epididymis torsion with scrotal pearl formation

Problem #3: 
Essential thrombocytosis, stable on Ruxolitinib with mild thrombocytosis

PLAN:
1. Continue observation of right hydrocele as symptoms have improved; no indication for surgical intervention at this time.

2. Patient to monitor for any recurrence of scrotal pain, swelling, or fever and return if symptoms worsen.

3. Continue current medications including Ruxolitinib for essential thrombocytosis.

4. Discussed hydrocelectomy as an option if symptoms worsen, noting that it would require clearance from hematology regarding perioperative Ruxolitinib management.

5. Follow up in 6 months for reassessment, sooner if symptoms return or worsen.

6. Patient to continue care with hematology, pain management, and neurology for management of other medical conditions.

7. PSA remains stable and within normal limits; continue annual screening.

Mr. King is a 52-year-old male with a history of right renal cell carcinoma s/p robotic right partial nephrectomy on 3/8/2024 (T1a Nx M0, G2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma with negative margins). He was incidentally found to have a 3 cm right renal mass on ultrasound performed for fatty liver evaluation. His most recent MRI from 7/2/2025 shows no evidence of recurrence. 

Patient also has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis with prior left ureteroscopy and laser lithotripsy in 2019 (stone analysis showed 45% calcium oxalate monohydrate, 40% calcium oxalate dihydrate, and 15% calcium phosphate). Patient is being managed for hypogonadism with testosterone cypionate 150 mg IM weekly. Recent testosterone level from 4/30/2025 was 449 ng/dL, which is within normal range.

He continues on HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with emtricitabine/tenofovir (Descovy), which was switched from Truvada in January 2024 due to planned partial nephrectomy. He reports 4 stable sexual partners in the last 3 months with no condom use. He has recently noted RUQ abdominal pain. ASSESSMENT: 
52-year-old male with a history of right renal cell carcinoma status post partial nephrectomy in March 2024, with clear cell histology, Fuhrman grade 2, pT1a NX M0 with negative margins. Most recent imaging in July 2025 shows no evidence of disease recurrence, indicating excellent prognosis. Patient also has history of recurrent nephrolithiasis with current small left kidney stone and predisposing risk factors including low urine volume, hypocitraturia, and high urinary pH. His hypogonadism is well-controlled on testosterone replacement therapy. He has recently developed abdominal pain likely related to newly diagnosed biliary dyskinesia and duodenal diverticulum requiring GI/surgical evaluation.

Problem #1: 
RIGHT RENAL CELL CARCINOMA: Status post right partial nephrectomy 3/8/2024 for 3.5 cm pT1a NX M0 Fuhrman grade 2 clear cell renal cell carcinoma with negative margins. Recent MRI (7/2/2025) showed no evidence of recurrence. Continue surveillance per guidelines.

Problem #2: 
RECURRENT NEPHROLITHIASIS: Last stone analysis showed calcium oxalate monohydrate (45%), calcium oxalate dihydrate (40%), and calcium phosphate (15%). CT 11/25/2024 showed a 3 mm nonobstructing left renal stone. 24-hour urine studies show low urine volume, hypocitraturia, high urinary pH, and elevated stone risk indices for calcium oxalate, brushite, and sodium urate.

Problem #3: 
HYPOGONADISM: Well-controlled on testosterone cypionate 150 mg IM weekly with most recent testosterone level at 449 ng/dL. Patient has osteopenia likely related to prior androgen deprivation and requires ongoing calcium and vitamin D supplementation.

1. RENAL CELL CARCINOMA:

   - Annual chest X-ray to evaluate for pulmonary metastases
   - Return to clinic in 6 months for follow-up

2. NEPHROLITHIASIS:
   - Increase fluid intake to achieve urine output >2 L/day
   - Limit dietary sodium to <2 g/day
   - Start potassium citrate 10 mEq PO BID to increase urinary citrate and lower urinary pH
   - Continue monitoring small left renal stone
   - Repeat 24-hour urine studies in 6 months

3. HYPOGONADISM:
   - Continue testosterone cypionate 150 mg IM weekly
   - Add calcium 600 mg/Vitamin D 400 IU PO BID for osteopenia
   - Repeat testosterone levels and CBC in 6 months
   - Repeat DEXA scan in 1 year

4. OTHER:
   - Refer to general surgery for evaluation of biliary dyskinesia and duodenal diverticulum
   - Consider wrist splint for newly diagnosed right carpal tunnel syndrome per neurology
   - Continue Descovy for PrEP; emphasize importance of safe sex practices
   - Return to urology clinic in 6 months

# VA UROLOGY CLINIC NOTE

CC: Follow-up for mixed urinary incontinence and endometriosis

HPI: Symone Owens is a 49-year-old female with a longstanding history of mixed urinary incontinence, who presents for follow-up evaluation. At her last appointment on 7/29/24, she was noted to have a septated/complex left cystic ovarian/adnexal mass (4.8 cm) with signal intensity suggesting endometriosis on MRI, with mass effect on the left superior bladder wall. She was referred to gynecology for treatment and underwent hysterectomy and left oophorectomy in November 2024. Despite the surgery, she continues to experience stress and urge incontinence symptoms. Patient reports she previously tried Detrol LA 4mg daily without significant improvement. She also completed pelvic floor physical therapy with limited benefit. She notes occasional "hot flashes" at night since her surgery and reports decreased libido. Her urinary symptoms typically worsen during stress activities such as coughing, laughing, and sneezing. She currently uses 2 pads per day for protection.

MSK: Bilateral chronic hip pain. No myalgias or new bone pain

PHYSICAL EXAM:

 
GENERAL: well developed, well nourished, gentleman with appropriate 
orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
HEENT: normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to palpation
CHEST: normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
ABDOMEN: soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally.

RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or rectal masses.

ASSESSMENT: Ms. Owens is a 49-year-old female with persistent mixed urinary incontinence despite undergoing hysterectomy and left oophorectomy in November 2024 for endometriosis. She previously failed therapy with Detrol LA and pelvic floor physical therapy. Her post-void residual on previous testing was excellent at 11.1 mL, indicating good bladder emptying. She continues to experience both stress and urge components, requiring the use of 2 pads per day. Patient's mild leukopenia and neutropenia are noted but unrelated to her urologic issues.


Problem #1: Mixed urinary incontinence (stress and urge components)
Problem #2: Status post hysterectomy and left oophorectomy for endometriosis (11/2024)
Problem #3: Decreased libido related to hormonal changes post-surgery


PLAN:

1. For mixed urinary incontinence:
   - Discontinue Detrol LA as it has not been effective
   - Start Myrbetriq (mirabegron) 25mg daily for 4 weeks, then increase to 50mg daily if tolerated for treatment of urgency component
   - Continue pelvic floor exercises and consider advanced pelvic floor therapy if patient desires
   - Discuss surgical options for stress urinary incontinence component:
     a) Midurethral sling procedure (TVT or TOT)
     b) Periurethral bulking agent injections
   - Patient expresses interest in sling procedure; provided education on risks, benefits, and expectations
   - Will schedule cystoscopy and urodynamic testing before proceeding with surgical intervention

2. For decreased libido:
   - Consider referral to gynecology for evaluation of hormonal therapy given her surgical menopause status
   - Counsel on use of vaginal moisturizers and lubricants as needed

3. Follow-up in 2 months to review response to Myrbetriq and proceed with urodynamic testing and cystoscopy as indicated. Will schedule surgery based on urodynamic findings.

4. Patient to call sooner for any signs of urinary tract infection, hematuria, or worsening symptoms.

 definitive IMRT radiation therapy completed in July 2022. His PSA has 
 appropriately declined to 0.20 ng/mL, which is an excellent nadir and 
 suggests good disease control. His lower urinary tract symptoms are minimal 
 on tamsulosin with an IPSS score of only 1/35. He has multiple medical 
 comorbidities including atrial fibrillation and DVT requiring 
 anticoagulation, diabetes, and hypertension, all of which appear well-
 controlled. He continues to have erectile dysfunction and would benefit from 
 alternative approaches to injection therapy.
 
 Problem #1: Prostate Cancer, cT1c, Gleason 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), s/p IMRT

 0.20, near nadir. Continue monitoring with PSA every 6 months.
 
 Problem #2: BPH w/ minimal LUTS - symptoms well controlled on tamsulosin with 
 IPSS 1/35. Continue current management.
 
 Problem #3: Erectile dysfunction - Patient has discontinued ICI due to pain 
 and difficulty with self-administration. VED provides limited benefit.

 ASSESSMENT: Mr. Cann is a 67-year-old man with a history of T1c cN0 M0 
 Gleason 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1) adenocarcinoma of the prostate who underwent 
 definitive IMRT radiation therapy completed in July 2022. His PSA has 
 appropriately declined to 0.20 ng/mL, which is an excellent nadir and 
 suggests good disease control. His lower urinary tract symptoms are minimal 
 on tamsulosin with an IPSS score of only 1/35. He has multiple medical 
 comorbidities including atrial fibrillation and DVT requiring 
 anticoagulation, diabetes, and hypertension, all of which appear well-
 controlled. He continues to have erectile dysfunction and would benefit from 
 alternative approaches to injection therapy.
 
 Problem #1: Prostate Cancer, cT1c, Gleason 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), s/p IMRT 
 completed 07/19/22. PSA has responded appropriately with current value at 
 0.20, near nadir. Continue monitoring with PSA every 6 months.
 
 Problem #2: BPH w/ minimal LUTS - symptoms well controlled on tamsulosin with 
 IPSS 1/35. Continue current management.
 
 Problem #3: Erectile dysfunction - Patient has discontinued ICI due to pain 
 and difficulty with self-administration. VED provides limited benefit. 
 Discussed IPP.
 
 Problem #4: Male Hypogonadism.  Mild.  May need a followup DEXA for this 
 however. 
 
 Problem #5:  Scrotal pain.  Has had this before a few years ago.  Will repeat 
 the scrotal US for the next visit in 2 months.
 
 PLAN:
 
 1. Continue PSA monitoring every 6 months - next due November 2025
 2. Continue tamsulosin for BPH management
 3. For ED: Discuss PDE5 inhibitor options (if no contraindications with 
 cardiac medications) and consider referral to sexual health specialist for 
 additional options
 4. Risk factor modification: Continue current exercise routine, vegan diet, 
 and weight management
 5. Return to clinic in 6 months with UA, DEXA and PSA
 6. Continue follow-up with hematology for anticoagulation management
 
 
 RTC in 2 months to review results of DEXA and scrotal US.  Other labs in 6 month 
 from now.

        HISTORY: S/P radiation 
       PROCEDURE: 
       Using a GE Lunar Prodigy Advance Model scanner, the bone mineral 
       density within the lumbar spine and left proximal femur was 
       measured.  
       FINDINGS: 
       The L1-L4 region bone mineral density is 1.555 g/cm2 which is 2.8 
       standard deviations above the mean, corresponding to the criteria 
       for normal bone mineral density.  
       T -- score = 2.8 g/cm2 , Z -- score = 1.8.  
       The left femoral neck bone mineral density is 1.171 g/cm2 which 
       is 0.8 standard deviations above the mean, corresponding to the 
       criteria for normal bone mineral density. 
       T -- score = 0.8, Z -- score = 0.3.  
       The total left hip bone mineral density is 1.213 g/cm2 which is 
       0.8 standard deviations above the mean, corresponding to the 
       criteria for normal bone mineral density.  
       T -- score = 0.8, Z -- score = -0.1.  
     Impression:
       This patient's T-score falls within the normal bone mineral 
       density range. 
       There is no prior exam to trend change in bone mineral density.  
       Based on the United States FRAX calculator, the patient's 10 year 
       probability of major osteoporotic fracture is 1.5% and 10 year 
       probability of hip fracture is 0.0%. 
       According to the World Health Organization guidelines, 
       osteoporosis may be diagnosed if the lowest T-score of the lumbar 
       spine, total hip or femoral neck is -2.5 or less.  Low bone 
       density (osteopenia) may be diagnosed if the T-score falls 
       between -1.0 and -2.5.  In certain circumstances the 33% radius 
       (also called 1/3rd radius) may be utilized.  
       Osteoporosis may be diagnosed in men age 50 and older if the 
       T-score of the lumbar spine, total hip or femoral neck is -2.5 or 
       less.  
       RECOMMENDATIONS: 
       1.  If therapy is contemplated, mild to aggressive therapies are 
       available.  Additionally, all patients should ensure an adequate 
       intake of dietary calcium (1200 mg/day) and vitamin D (400-800 IU 
       daily).  
       2.  The National Osteoporosis Foundation (NOF) guidelines 
       recommend initiating therapy to reduce fracture risk in 
       postmenopausal women or men over age 50 with BMD: - T-score below
       -2.5 SD; - or T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 SD if the 10-year
       probability of hip fracture is >3% or a 10-year probability of a
       major osteoporosis-related fracture is >20% based on the
       U.S.-adapted WHO algorithm; - or presence of a fragility
       fracture.  
       3. Patients with diagnosed cases of osteoporosis or low bone 
       density (osteopenia) should be regularly tested for bone mineral 
       density.  For patients eligible for Medicare, routine testing is 
       allowed once every 2 years.  Testing frequency can be increased 
       for patients with rapidly progressing disease, or for those who 
       are receiving medical therapy to restore bone mass.  
       COMMENTS: 
       The technical quality of the study is good.

       COMPARISON: CT 2/23/2020, ultrasound 6/7/2018 and CT scan 
       1/13/2012 
       FINDINGS: Lung bases are clear. Cardiac chambers are within
       normal limits.  No pericardial effusion. Patulous appearance of
       the esophagus and small hiatal hernia suggests GERD. The liver
       demonstrates diffuse hypodensity which is indicative of hepatic
       steatosis. No focal liver lesion. Mixing artifact visualized
       along the lumen of the portal vein due to technique and phase.
       Gallbladder appears unremarkable. No abnormality visualized along
       the pancreas.  Adrenals are within normal limits. 7 mm cyst is
       visualized in the upper pole of the right kidney. 1.5 cm cyst is
       visualized in the lower pole of the right kidney. This cyst
       demonstrates fluid attenuation. No hydronephrosis or hyperdense
       stones in the right kidney. There is a cyst in the lower pole of
       the left kidney measuring 2.2 cm. This cyst demonstrates fluid
       attenuation. No hydronephrosis or hyperdense stones. Bladder
       appears unremarkable. The bowel gas pattern is nonobstructive.  
       Anastomotic sutures are visualized in the distal intestine.  
       Colonic structures are unremarkable. Appendix is within normal 
       limits. No free air or free fluid. There is a fat-containing 
       large ventral hernia with a sac that measures roughly 8 cm in 
       diameter and an os that measures 4.8 cm in diameter. The larger 
       sac is eccentric towards the right. There is no intrusion of 
       bowel loops which are marginally seen near the defect of the 
       fascia. Stranding is visualized along the subcutaneous 
       compartment of the abdominal wall tracking towards the skin. This 
       may be postsurgical in nature.  No acute osseous abnormality with
       multilevel spondylosis of the thoracic spine and lumbar spine.  
     Impression:
       1. Nonobstructive bowel gas pattern.  2. No hydronephrosis with
       stable appearance of renal cysts.  3. Large ventral
       fat-containing abdominal hernia.  4. Hepatic steatosis.

       1 injection(s) performed.  Injection Event (Yes or No): No.  
       Up-to-date CT equipment and radiation dose reduction techniques 
       were employed. CTDIvol: 24.0 mGy. DLP: 1338 mGy-cm.
