     Verifier E-Sig:/ES/ABHIJIT SUNNAPWAR
     Report:
       EXAM:  CT of the Abdomen and Pelvis 
       TECHNIQUE: Axial helical CT scans of the abdomen and pelvis were 
       obtained after administration of oral and IV contrast.  
       HISTORY:possible recurrent umbilical hernia 
       COMPARISON: 12/23/2011 
       FINDINGS: 
       There is approximately 9.2 cm of rectus diastasis noted at the 
       umbilicus with a predominant 5.7 AP x 6.3 TR x 7.3 CC cm
       mesentery containing hernia. There are smaller adjacent
       mesenteric hernias into the more lateral fashion. The one on the
       left measures 2.5 AP x 4.2 TR x 6.6 CC cm  and the smaller one on
       the right measures 1.8 AP x 2.6 TR x 4.2 CC cm. Finally there is
       a questionable smaller rectal fashion defect with mesentery
       containing fat herniation right lateral to the smaller
       right-sided hernia which contains a tiny portion of small bowel
       which does not appear incarcerated or strangulated. With in each 
       of these hernia sacs there is no fat stranding or fluid
       to this region of herniation. These herniations appear unchanged
       since 12/23/2011.  
       No focal abnormalities are seen in the liver, spleen, or
       pancreas.  
       The gallbladder is normal without stones, pericholecystic fluid,
       or gallbladder wall thickening.  No biliary dilatation is
       present. 
       The adrenal glands and kidneys are normal with the exception of
       an unchanged 1.2 cm simple cyst in the posterior midpole region
       of the left kidney.  The ureters are normal in course and caliber
       en route to the bladder which appears unremarkable. There is a
       small right-sided fat-containing hernia seen.  
       The prostate and seminal vesicles are unremarkable. No free 
       intraperitoneal air or fluid is identified..  
       The large and small bowel are normal. The appendix is normal.  No 
       stranding is seen in the mesenteric fat.  No free peritoneal air
       or fluid is seen.  The peritoneal and retroperitoneal lymph nodes
       are not pathologically enlarged.  
       Sutures a normal noncontrast appearance. Multilevel degenerative
       disc disease is seen along the thoracolumbar spine. Vacuum
       phenomenon is seen at L4-L5 without disk space narrowing.  There
       is a small nitrogen containing bone cyst noted at L5. Severe
       bilateral SI joint arthropathy is noted with bridging osteophytes
       seen.  
       The lung bases are normal.  
     Impression:
       Unchanged hernias in the anterior abdominal wall as described
       without signs of incarceration or strangulation.

     Verifier E-Sig:/ES/Shaile CHOUDHARY
     Report:
       EXAMINATION: CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast.  
       CLINICAL HISTORY: 53-year-old male status post umbilical hernia
       repair with bilateral mesh secondary to incarcerated epigastric
       hernia.  Patient now with open wound and a large amount of dark
       maroon drainage with concern for underlying abscess.  
       TECHNIQUE: Multiple, contiguous 5 mm axial CT images of the
       abdomen and pelvis were obtained after administration of oral and
       intravenous contrast.  
       COMPARISON: CT examinations of the abdomen and pelvis with
       contrast dated 10/08/2010 and 08/03/2010 
       FINDINGS: 
       The patient is status post paraumbilical hernia repair. An open 
       midline laparotomy wound is appreciated seen. Subcutaneous
       emphysema is seen in the anterior fibrofatty soft tissue layer.
       There is stranding and edema within the surgical wound as well as
       bandage material seen overlying the surgical wound. There is a
       3.1 (AP) x 5.2 (TR) x 4.8 (CC) cm intra-abdominal hypodense
       lesion with enhancing rim along the left side of the indwelling
       surgical hernia mesh with surrounding mesenteric stranding. Mild
       mesenteric stranding is also seen in the right lower quadrant,
       likely postsurgical in.  
       The liver, spleen, pancreas, and adrenal glands are unremarkable.  
       There has been no significant interval change in the multiple 
       hypodense lesions seen in both kidneys measuring up to a 1.3 cm.
       Most of these lesions are too small to further characterize,
       however, statistically they most likely represent simple cysts.
       The gallbladder has a normal appearance with no biliary dilation
       identified.  The urinary bladder is unremarkable. The prostate is
       normal in size and appearance.  
       The distal esophagus and stomach are within normal limits. The
       small bowel are unremarkable. The appendix is normal. A few
       diverticula are seen scattered throughout the colon. No free
       intraperitoneal air is identified. No enlarged lymph nodes are
       seen. The abdominal aorta and its major branches are grossly
       unremarkable.  
       A small fat-containing right inguinal hernia is seen.
       Degenerative changes are again seen in the visualized spine and
       both hips. No acute or suspicious osseous lesions are seen.  
       The visualized portions of the heart have a normal appearance. 
       Mild bibasilar atelectasis is appreciated, otherwise the lung
       bases are clear.  
     Impression:
       3.1 (AP) x 5.2 (TR) cm intra-abdominal 
       posterolateral aspect of the indwelling surgical hernia mesh with 
       surrounding mesenteric stranding. This is concerning for abscess 
       formation.  
       I, the attending physician, have personally reviewed the image or 
       images as well as the resident's interpretation and either agree
       with the interpretation or have edited the findings.

       Degenerative changes are seen in the spine and pelvis.  No focal
       soft tissue abnormality is seen.  
       Dependent atelectasis is seen bilaterally.  
     Impression:
       1. A large ventral abdominal hernia now contains a portion of the 
       transverse colon and a mildly dilated loop of small bowel.  Fat 
       stranding within the hernial sac likely secondary to
       incarceration.  Early or impending small bowel obstruction or
       strangulation is not excluded. 
       2. A second smaller fat containing periumbilical hernia is also
       seen.  
       3. Hepatic steatosis.  
       I, the attending physician, have personally reviewed the image or 
       images as well as the resident's interpretation and either agree
       with the interpretation or have edited the findings.

 RIGHT KNEE ARTHROSCOPY (9-15) - KNEE ARTHROSCOPY/SURGERY

 RIGHT KNEE MENISCAL TEAR
Surgeon's Dictation
                               OPERATION REPORT
 DATE OF OPERATION:   08/21/2000  TIME BEGAN:   9:22  TIME ENDED:   10:27
 PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Right knee pain with medial joint line tenderness.
 POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Status post right knee arthroscopy with medial
 meniscus tear status post debridement of that tear.
 NAME OF OPERATION:   RIGHT KNEE ARTHROSCOPY (9-15)
   SURGERY:  MAJOR  X    MINOR
 STAFF:   MILTON C BUTLER
  PRESENT IN:  OR X   SUITE      HSC/VA     CONSULTED
 SURGEON:   STACE S RUST MD
 FIRST ASSISTANT:   GARY A GO
 ANESTHESIA:  General endotracheal.
 ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:  Less than 10.
 INTRAOPERATIVE FLUIDS:  800 of crystalloid.
 DRAINS:  None.
 COMPLICATIONS:
 !!!
 INDICATIONS FOR OPERATION:  The patient had a history of right knee pain
 with medial joint line tenderness.
 OPERATIVE FINDINGS:
 DESCRIPTION OF OPERATION/PROCEDURE:  After consent was obtained from the
 patient he was taken to operating room #3 and positioned supine on the
 operating table.  His right lower extremity was prepped and draped in the
 usual sterile fashion this after applying a tourniquet which was not used
 throughout the procedure.   Landmarks were marked with marking pen.  A
 50/50 mixture of Duramorph and  0.25% Marcaine 8 cc of this mixture was
 instilled into three places for portals, superior lateral and inferior
 medial and lateral.
 The ports were all made on the knee.  The camera trocar was inserted via
 the inferolateral port.  The suprapatellar pouch was investigated and found
 to have no loose bodies.  The inferior patella was investigated and seen to
 have minimal chondromalacia, some synovitis about the suprapatellar pouch.
 Attention was turned to the medial gutter were no loose bodies, no
 synovitis was found.  The medial joint line was then inspected and a
 horizontal tear of the posterior horn of the medial meniscus from the
 margin back to about two-thirds of the disc was found.  This tear was
 saucerized with a straight biter and a shaver and it was very smooth after
 debridement.  The medial femoral condyle had grade III-IV chondromalacia
 about it.  The tibial plateau had mild chondromalacia.  The ACL was intact
 and stable.
 Attention was turned next to the lateral compartment.  It showed a
 pristine-looking lateral meniscus, no tears, no fibrillations.  The tibial
 plateau showed some grade III chondromalacia.  The lateral femoral condyle
 was clean.  The lateral gutter was then inspected and we found no loose
 bodies, no synovitis.  The popliteal tendon was inspected and was in good
 shape.
 The medial compartment was then once again inspected and it was found,
 after debridement of the medial posterior horn tear, that the femoral
 condyle moved over rather smoothly.  Like I said before, the posterior horn
 was saucerized and smoothed with the shaver, all loose bodies were washed
 out of the knee.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  Needle and
 sponge counts were correct at the end of the case.  The trocars were
 removed.  The three incisions were sutured with one each interrupted 2-0
 nylon suture.  Xeroform, fluffs and Webril were applied to the patient's
 knee and he was taken to the Recovery Room in good shape.  The family was
 spoken to at the end of the case.

      involved. The opposite margin appears to have an area of pinker, more
      healthy appearing serosa that extends approximately 1.5 cm from the
      margin.  The small bowel is 18 cm in length and has attached
      mesenteric fat that has been trimmed and has a diameter of
      approximately 1.5 cm.  Opening the bowel reveals scant particles of
      fecal material and a maroon-purple mucosa that is edematous.  The wall
      thickness is approximately 7 cm throughout.  
      Now onto the other fragments in the container: there is a fragment of
      what appears just to be mesenteric fat that is yellow lobulated,
      measuring 19 x 10 x 3.5 cm.  There is another piece of adipose tissue
      with attached serosal-like tissue measuring 8 x 5 x 3.5 cm.  The
      serosa appears to be dusky purple to pink in coloration.  Another
      piece of tissue contains erythematous appearing opened membranous
      material that is blood stained with attached adipose tissue measuring
      15 x 10 x 4 cm.  The next piece is what appears to be a pouch-like
      opened sac with dark red dusky mucosa and serosa measuring 10 x 4 x 2
      cm.  There is also an additional piece of smaller opened pouch-like
      serosal that is pink-tan in coloration with attached adipose tissue
      measuring 6 x 3 x 2.5 cm.  Representative sections submitted as
      follows: in Cassette S10-7073 A1-sections of the small bowel closed by

 ASSESSMENT: Mr. Cann is a 67-year-old man with a history of T1c cN0 M0 
 Gleason 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1) adenocarcinoma of the prostate who underwent 
 definitive IMRT radiation therapy completed in July 2022. His PSA has 
 appropriately declined to 0.20 ng/mL, which is an excellent nadir and 
 suggests good disease control. His lower urinary tract symptoms are minimal 
 on tamsulosin with an IPSS score of only 1/35. He has multiple medical 
 comorbidities including atrial fibrillation and DVT requiring 
 anticoagulation, diabetes, and hypertension, all of which appear well-
 controlled. He continues to have erectile dysfunction and would benefit from 
 alternative approaches to injection therapy.
 
 Problem #1: Prostate Cancer, cT1c, Gleason 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), s/p IMRT 
 completed 07/19/22. PSA has responded appropriately with current value at 
 0.20, near nadir. Continue monitoring with PSA every 6 months.
 
 Problem #2: BPH w/ minimal LUTS - symptoms well controlled on tamsulosin with 
 IPSS 1/35. Continue current management.
 
 Problem #3: Erectile dysfunction - Patient has discontinued ICI due to pain 
 and difficulty with self-administration. VED provides limited benefit. 
 Discussed IPP.

 however.

 the scrotal US for the next visit in 2 months.

rectal masses.

CNS: Grossly intact motor function and sensation.

ASSESSMENT: 
Mr. Perez is a 70-year-old male with low-risk prostate cancer (T1c, Grade Group 1) on active surveillance. His current PSA is 7.76 ng/mL, showing significant improvement from previous values of 10.37-14.85 ng/mL over the past year. Recent MRI demonstrates stable disease with PI-RADS 4 and 5 lesions in the left mid peripheral zone without evidence of progression. He also has moderate BPH with stable LUTS on finasteride after discontinuing tamsulosin due to side effects. His declining PSA trend suggests resolution of the presumed prostatitis component that contributed to his elevated PSA last year. Other findings include newly diagnosed hiatal hernia and coronary artery calcification that warrant appropriate follow-up.

Problem #1: Low-risk prostate cancer (T1c, Gleason 3+3=6, Grade Group 1)
- PSA showing improving trend with current value of 7.76 ng/mL
- Stable MRI findings without evidence of progression
- Meeting criteria for continued active surveillance per NCCN guidelines

Problem #2: BPH with LUTS
- IPSS score 18/35, stable symptoms
- Intolerant to tamsulosin
- Currently on finasteride with adequate control of symptoms

Problem #3: Moderate-sized hiatal hernia
- Identified on recent CT chest
- Provides explanation for dysphagia symptoms
- Consider GI referral for management

Problem #4: Cardiovascular risk factors
- Coronary calcium score of 135 Agatston units
- Multiple risk factors including diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia
- On appropriate medication management

PLAN:

1. Continue active surveillance for prostate cancer:
   - Repeat PSA in 3 months
   - Discuss repeat prostate biopsy in 12 months (2 years from last biopsy) per NCCN guidelines
   - Continue monitoring with annual MRIs

2. Management of LUTS/BPH:
   - Continue finasteride 5mg daily
   - Maintain dietary modifications (limit caffeine, alcohol, bladder irritants)
   - Consider alternative alpha blocker if symptoms worsen

3. Cardiovascular and metabolic management:
   - Continue current medications for diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia
   - Encourage lifestyle modifications including diet and exercise
   - Follow up with primary care regarding coronary calcium findings

4. Other recommendations:
   - Consider GI consultation for evaluation and management of hiatal hernia
   - Return to clinic in 3 months with repeat PSA
   - Consider urodynamic evaluation if urinary symptoms worsen

The patient was counseled regarding active surveillance protocol, including the risks, benefits, and alternatives. He understands the need for continued close monitoring with PSA testing, imaging, and repeat biopsy in the future. The patient expressed understanding and agreement with the plan.

 CC:  Follow-up for active surveillance of prostate cancer.
 HPI: The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of low-risk prostate 
 cancer (Gleason 3+3=6, Grade Group 1) diagnosed in June 2022. He has been on 
 active surveillance. His most recent prostate biopsy in January 2023 confirmed 
 Grade Group 1 prostate adenocarcinoma, with involvement of 90% in the target 
 area and up to 40% in the left medial mid core. His PSA has been monitored 
 regularly, with the most recent value on December 26, 2024, at 10.37 ng/mL, 
 which is elevated, but as high as previous levels. 
 The patient denies any new urinary symptoms. He continues to take tamsulosin for 
 mild lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and reports good symptom control. 
 The patient has been adherent to active surveillance protocols, including PSA 
 monitoring and prior prostate biopsies. He has not undergone prostate MRI since 
 his initial diagnosis. He expresses concern about the rising PSA and is open to 
 further evaluation.

 ASSESSMENT: 69-year-old Latin American male with history of T1 cNX MX Gleason 3+
 3 equal 6 adenocarcinoma the prostate and 5 out of 12 cores with initial PSA of 
 8.5 on active surveillance.  His PSA abruptly rose to over 14 and then within a 
 short period came down to 11 concomitant with a course of antibiotics for H.

 problem #1.Low-risk prostate cancer (Gleason 3+3=6, Grade Group 1): 
    - PSA elevation to 10.37 ng/mL, rising trend over the past year. 
    - Biopsy-confirmed low-risk disease with no evidence of progression on prior

    - Mild LUTS, well-controlled on tamsulosin.

    - Controlled on metformin. 
 Problem #4.Hyperlipidemia: 
    - Stable on atorvastatin. 
 Problem #5.Hypertension: 
    - Well-controlled on lisinopril. 
 PLAN:
 1.Prostate Cancer: 
    - Order repeat prostate MRI in 6 months to evaluate for any interval changes, 
 including extracapsular extension or significant lesion progression. 
    - Consider repeat prostate biopsy in 12 months per is PSA rises per NCCN 
 guidelines for active surveillance. 
    - Continue PSA monitoring every 6 months. 
 2.BPH: 
    - Discontinue tamsulosin as he did not tolerate.  Start Finasteride.  He was 
 happy to hear it might promote some hair growth. 
    - Dietary restrictions of caffeinated products and other bladder irritants 
 3.Diabetes, Hyperlipidemia, and Hypertension: 
    - Continue current medications. 
    - Follow up with primary care for routine management. 
 4.Follow-Up: 
    - Return to clinic in 6 months to review MRI results and PSA trends. 
 The patient was counseled on the importance of continued active surveillance, 
 including the need for repeat imaging and potentially biopsy depending on MR 
 results and PSA results. Risks, benefits, and alternatives to active 
 surveillance were discussed, including definitive treatment options such as 
 radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy. The patient expressed understanding 
 and agreement with the plan.

 CC: Active surveillance for prostate cancer
 HPI: Joseph is a very pleasant 69-year-old Latin American male with a history of 
 grade group 1 prostate cancer and 5 out of 12 cores with initial PSA of 8.5 who 
 is currently on active surveillance and is undergone 2 separate biopsies.  The 
 first biopsy was in June 2022, and the second biopsy was in January 2023.  His 
 initial MRI demonstrated a PI-RADS 5 and PI-RADS 4 lesion.  A subsequent MRI 
 performed in April demonstrates stability of the PI-RADS 5 lesion and slight 
 interval growth of the PI-RADS 4 lesion.  Concomitant with his MRI he had also 
 PSA levels drawn and they abruptly went up to as high as 14.  His most recent 
 PSA is 11.  Also over the last few months he was found to have H. pylori and was 
 placed on oral antibiotics for this including doxycycline and metronidazole. 
 The timing of his antibiotics coincides with the decrease in his PSA level.  He 
 also had a worsening of urinary symptoms starting early in this year 
 particularly with urinary frequency and urgency and some intermittency.  Overall 
 it appears he may have had some inflammatory issues with his prostate that led 
 to the abrupt rise in the PSA and there may have been treated or partially 
 treated with the antibiotics intended for his H. pylori.  He is diabetic.

 ASSESSMENT: 69-year-old Latin American male with history of T1 cNX MX Gleason 3+
 3 equal 6 adenocarcinoma the prostate and 5 out of 12 cores with initial PSA of 
 8.5 on active surveillance.  His PSA abruptly rose to over 14 and then within a 
 short period came down to 11 concomitant with a course of antibiotics for H. 
 pylori.  His urinary symptoms also significantly flared during this time 
 interval and have not yet fully resolved.
 Problem #1: Prostate cancer.  His MRI of the prostate demonstrates a PI-RADS 5 
 lesion which is stable in which the target lesion for his prostate biopsy 
 performed in 2023 demonstrating Gleason 6 disease.  There is a second lesion on 
 the left that is PI-RADS 4 that seems to have grown slightly and is a little 
 more noticeable than before.  However it is also possible that this is related 
 to some inflammation, and given his symptoms and PSA changes and his response to 
 the H. pylori antibiotics, I would like to give him Cipro for a month to ensure 
 that we fully eradicated any residual bacteria in the prostate.  Subsequently we 
 can repeat the PSA and then make further recommendations.  If the PSA remains 
 persistently elevated, then a biopsy would be indicated.
 Problem #2: BPH with lower urinary tract symptoms.  I am concerned that the 
 acute worsening of his urinary symptoms may be related to an underlying 
 prostatitis, particularly with his PSA going up into the 14 range.  I am giving 
 him a course of Cipro for a month and see him back in 4 months and reassess him 
 at that point.  He was also counseled on dietary modifications.  I renewed his 
 prescription for Flomax.
 PLAN:
 Renew prescription for tamsulosin
 Dietary restrictions of caffeinated products and other bladder irritants
 Ciprofloxacin for 1 month
 Return to clinic in 4 months with repeat PSA, UA, and metabolic panel.

     Clinical History:

                                               Date Verified: JUL 13, 2025
     Verifier E-Sig:/ES/HUGH D WHITE
     Report:
       Comparison: Prostate MRI dated 4/16/24.  
       History: Active Surveillance for prostate cancer 
       Technique: Multiplanar, multisequence magnetic resonance images 
       of the pelvis were obtained before and after the administration 
       of gadolinium IV contrast. Imaging was performed on a 3T MRI and 
       in accordance with PI-RADS v2.1 standards.  
       Findings: 
       The prostate gland measures 4.6 x 3.2 x 5.8 cm. This equates to a 
       volume of 44 cubic cm. 
       There is moderate transitional zone nodular hypertrophy. 
       There has been no significant size change in the PI-RADS 5 lesion 
       in the left posterolateral mid peripheral zone measuring up to 
       1.6 cm.  
       Also not significantly changed is the PI-RADS 4 lesion in the 
       lateral left mid peripheral zone measuring up to 1.0 cm. 
       No new lesions are seen. 
       There is no evidence of capsular disruption/extracapsular 
       extension. The neurovascular bundles are intact. The seminal 
       vesicles are symmetric.  
       No enlarged pelvic lymph nodes are present.  
       The urinary bladder is within normal limits.  
       The visualized bowel is within normal limits.  
       A fat-containing indirect right inguinal hernia is present. 
       The visualized bones are within normal limits.  
     Impression:
       Stable PI-RADS 4 and 5 lesions in the left mid peripheral zone.  
       No convincing evidence of extracapsular extension. No pelvic 
       adenopathy by size criteria.

       were employed. CTDIvol: 2.2 - 63.6 mGy. DLP: 332 mGy-cm.  
       COMPARISON: None.  
       CT ANGIOGRAM: The study is technically adequate with a good 
       contrast bolus to the pulmonary arterial tree. No central or 
       segmental pulmonary embolus. Evaluation of the subsegmental 
       arteries is limited by motion artifact. No aortic aneurysm or 
       dissection.  
       CHEST: Clear lungs. Bilateral calcified granulomas. No 
       endoluminal lesions identified within the central airways. 
       No pleural effusion, pleural thickening, or pneumothorax. 
       No pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph 
       nodes. 
       Mild coronary artery calcifications. No cardiomegaly or 
       pericardial effusion.  
       Marked diffuse concentric wall thickening of the distal esophagus 
       and/or moderate size hiatal hernia. 
       The unopacified esophagus appears grossly normal.  
       Degenerative changes throughout the visualized spine. No acute or 
       destructive osseous abnormality identified. Large right posterior 
       chest wall intramuscular lipoma.  
       UPPER ABDOMEN: Visualized upper abdominal viscera appear grossly 
       normal. 
     Impression:
        1. No CT evidence of central or segmental pulmonary embolus or 
       other acute intrathoracic abnormality. Evaluation of the 
       subsegmental pulmonary arteries is limited by motion artifact.  
       2. Marked diffuse concentric wall thickening of the distal 
       esophagus and/or moderate size hiatal hernia. Follow-up GI 
       consult recommended.  3. Chronic and/or incidental findings as

       zone.

       peripheral zone.

ASSESSMENT: Mr. Wallace is a 61-year-old male with history of BPH who underwent TURP on 2/27/2023 with excellent results. His urinary symptoms remain well-controlled with an IPSS score of 1/35. His PSA level has been stable since surgery and is within normal range at 3.58, though not as low as might be expected post-TURP. He has been newly diagnosed with moderate obstructive sleep apnea that will require follow-up with Sleep Medicine. He has no urologic complaints and continues to void well without medication. His vitamin D deficiency is being treated appropriately.

Problem #1: History of BPH s/p TURP
The patient continues to do well following TURP in February 2023. His IPSS score remains excellent at 1/35, with only mild nocturia reported as 1/night. He has normal urinary function with no need for medication therapy.

Problem #2: History of elevated PSA
The patient's post-TURP PSA has been relatively stable, though it has increased slightly from 3.01 last year to 3.58 currently. This value remains within normal range and is consistent with the presence of residual prostatic tissue following his TURP. Given the benign pathology from his TURP specimen, stable PSA without significant increase, and absence of symptoms, continued monitoring is appropriate.

Problem #3: Newly diagnosed moderate obstructive sleep apnea
Recently diagnosed via home sleep study with moderate OSA (pAHI-3% of 25.7/hr). Patient should follow up with Sleep Medicine for treatment options and management.

PLAN:
1. Continue monitoring PSA annually; current value of 3.58 is within normal range.
2. No need for BPH medications given excellent post-TURP outcomes.
3. Annual follow-up visit in urology with repeat PSA and IPSS in 12 months.
4. Recommended follow-up with sleep medicine for management of newly diagnosed moderate obstructive sleep apnea.
5. Continue vitamin D supplementation as prescribed by PCP.
6. Patient should discuss food sensitivities with PCP regarding gastrointestinal symptoms with seafood consumption.

# VA CLINIC NOTE

CC: Prostate cancer and BPH with lower urinary tract symptoms follow-up

HPI: Mr. Cook is a pleasant 76-year-old male with history of T1c NX MX Gleason 3+3=6 (GG1) adenocarcinoma of prostate first diagnosed in March 2016 and confirmed with 2 subsequent surveillance biopsies, the most recent in February 2021. He is currently on active surveillance. He also has BPH with LUTS controlled with dual medical therapy (tamsulosin 0.8 mg and finasteride 5 mg). He has erectile dysfunction currently treated with vardenafil 20 mg with good efficacy.

Since his last visit, he has developed mild neck pain on the right side over the past 2-3 weeks, described as dull and continuous, rated 4/10 but becoming 6/10 when worse. Pain is aggravated by looking to the right side. Patient has also noted tremors in his right thumb over the past 2-3 months, which typically occur at rest and when holding light objects like a newspaper. The tremor resolves spontaneously or when he grabs his thumb with another finger. He reports no changes in his urinary symptoms.

GENERAL: Well developed, well nourished, gentleman with appropriate orientation, mood, affect, demeanor and dress.
HEENT: Normal symmetric, non-tender neck without mass/thyromegaly to palpation. Muscle spasm noted on right side of neck.
CHEST: Normal respiratory effort; no gynecomastia or masses.
ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, without masses or organomegally. No palpable hernias.
GU: No CVAT, or bladder tenderness/fullness.
RECTAL: Normal anus and perineum; intact sphincter tone; no hemorrhoids or rectal masses.
PROSTATE: Normal size (35 gm), no palpable nodules.
CNS: Grossly intact motor function and sensation. Right thumb with intermittent fine tremor at rest.


ASSESSMENT: Mr. Cook is a 76-year-old male with low-risk prostate cancer (T1c NX MX GG1) on active surveillance since 2016. He has had several confirmatory biopsies showing stable disease, most recently in 2021, and his PSA has fluctuated between 5-6 ng/mL over the past year. He is on dual therapy for BPH with good symptom control. His most recent prostate MRI in April 2024 showed no significant change in his lesion. He has newly developed right-sided neck pain and right thumb tremor that warrant neurological evaluation, but these do not appear to be related to his urological conditions.


Problem #1: Prostate cancer - T1c NX MX GG1 (Gleason 3+3=6), on active surveillance since 2016. PSA stable in 5-6 range, with mild fluctuations. MRI in April 2024 without concerning changes. Based on NCCN guidelines for low-risk prostate cancer, continued active surveillance is appropriate given the stable disease and patient's well-controlled symptoms.

Problem #2: BPH with LUTS - Well-controlled on tamsulosin 0.8 mg BID and finasteride 5 mg daily. IPSS score of 12/35 with bother index of 2/6 indicates satisfactory symptom control. Will continue current management.

Problem #3: Erectile dysfunction - Managed with vardenafil 20 mg PRN with good efficacy. Patient notes occasional headaches as side effect but prefers to continue current regimen due to good therapeutic response.


PLAN:
1. Continue active surveillance for prostate cancer with PSA monitoring every 6 months
2. Schedule repeat prostate MRI in April 2026 (2-year interval)
3. Continue current BPH management with tamsulosin 0.8 mg BID and finasteride 5 mg daily
4. Continue vardenafil 20 mg PRN for ED
5. Return to urology clinic in 6 months with repeat PSA and urinalysis
6. Primary care to address new neurological symptoms (right neck pain and right thumb tremor) with appropriate referrals

# VA Clinic Note
August 18, 2025

CC: Follow-up for recent ED visit for hematuria

HPI:
Mr. Cole is a 66-year-old male with a history of prostate cancer s/p cryoablation in 2008, currently in remission with consistently low PSA levels (most recent 0.12 ng/mL on 4/22/25), who presents today for follow-up after an ED visit on 6/30/25 for gross hematuria with clots. During that ED visit, he received IV fluids with cefepime followed by cefdinir 300 mg twice daily. CT abdomen/pelvis on 6/30/25 showed "No acute abnormality in the abdomen or pelvis" with an unchanged 2.8 cm left adrenal adenoma, small left renal cyst, and evidence of prior prostatectomy with penile prosthesis in place. Urine culture from the ED visit showed Escherichia coli (10,000-100,000 CFU/mL), sensitive to multiple antibiotics. Patient reports completing the antibiotic course and denies any recurrence of hematuria since then. His urine has been clear and he denies any dysuria, frequency, urgency, or suprapubic pain.

ASSESSMENT: Mr. Cole is a 66-year-old male with a history of prostate cancer in remission following cryoablation in 2008, who presented with an episode of hematuria on 6/30/25. Urine culture showed E. coli UTI which was appropriately treated with antibiotics. His CT scan showed no evidence of urolithiasis, hydronephrosis, or other acute abnormalities. His PSA remains very low at 0.12, which is reassuring against prostate cancer recurrence. His hematuria has completely resolved following antibiotic treatment, suggesting the E. coli UTI was the likely etiology. His 3-piece IPP remains functional without complications.

Problem #1: Resolved hematuria/UTI
1. Hematuria has resolved after treatment with cefdinir
2. No evidence of recurrent hematuria
3. Most likely due to E. coli UTI which has been successfully treated

5. Recommend increased fluid intake to prevent recurrent UTIs
6. Return if hematuria recurs

Problem #2: History of prostate cancer, currently in remission
1. S/P cryoablation and radiation in 2008
2. PSA remains low at 0.12 ng/mL (4/22/25)
3. No evidence of recurrence
4. Continue annual PSA monitoring

1. IPP functioning well per patient report
2. No complaints of pain or mechanical issues
3. No signs of erosion or infection on exam

PLAN:
1. Continue current medications
2. Ensure adequate hydration to prevent recurrent UTIs
3. Return to clinic in 6 months for routine follow-up
4. Annual PSA monitoring to continue through primary care
5. Return sooner for recurrent hematuria, UTI symptoms (dysuria, frequency, urgency), or problems with penile prosthesis
6. Continue use of valacyclovir for HSV suppression
7. Follow up with Sleep Medicine for CPAP compliance evaluation

Dr. Ron Rodriguez, MD, PhD
VA Urology Clinic

Mr. Broadnax is a 78-year-old male with multiple comorbidities presenting for follow-up of his urologic conditions. His BPH symptoms are currently well-controlled on tamsulosin with a low IPSS score. - Most recent imaging (5/12/25) shows no evidence of recurrence

2. No immediate intervention needed for IPP as patient is not bothered by current function

# VA Clinic Note - Urology

CC: Follow-up of BPH with LUTS, left adrenal mass, and right breast mass.

HPI:
Mr. Martin Frias Jr. is an 81-year-old gentleman (DOB: 7/19/1944) returning to the VA Urology clinic for follow-up of multiple urologic conditions. He has a history of BPH on dual medical therapy (tamsulosin and finasteride) with lower urinary tract symptoms. His urinary symptoms are relatively stable with IPSS score improvement from 11/35 in July 2024 to 8/35 today. The patient continues to have nocturia x4, likely exacerbated by evening diuretic dosing. He has a large left adrenal mass (10 cm), described as a myelolipoma on imaging that has grown over two decades from 2.5 cm to 10 cm. This was discussed at tumor board on 3/12/2025, which recommended continued surveillance given the radiographic appearance and being asymptomatic. All adrenal labs have been normal.

Most recently, the patient had a CT urogram on 5/1/2025 for evaluation of microhematuria. This study showed no upper tract abnormalities but incidentally identified a 2 cm right breast mass concerning for malignancy. The patient was referred to medical oncology for evaluation of this breast mass. Since his last visit, the patient had an ED visit on 5/20/2025 for chest pain, which was determined to be non-cardiac in origin after negative troponin and normal stress test. The patient also had a prior episode of chest pain in November 2024 that was also determined to be non-cardiac.

He has a history of ED that has been well-managed with sildenafil. After being widowed in December 2023 (which coincided with an episode of acute urinary retention), the patient reports he has been dating again and is sexually active.

ASSESSMENT: Mr. Frias is an 81-year-old gentleman with multiple urologic conditions including BPH with LUTS, stable PSA, and a large left adrenal myelolipoma. His urinary symptoms remain relatively stable on dual medical therapy with tamsulosin and finasteride, with his primary complaint being nocturia. The 10 cm left adrenal mass has been reviewed by tumor board and deemed stable for continued surveillance. His microhematuria has been appropriately worked up with CT urogram showing no upper tract lesions, though there is an incidental right breast mass requiring prompt evaluation. His PSA remains stable and within normal range when corrected for finasteride. His ED is well-managed with sildenafil, and the patient reports satisfaction with his current regimen. The recent cardiac workup following chest pain was negative for ischemia with normal heart function.

Problem #1: BPH with LUTS
Patient has moderate BPH with prostate volume of 87cc and stable urinary symptoms on tamsulosin and finasteride. The patient continues to have nocturia likely exacerbated by evening diuretic dosing. PSA is stable at 1.73 ng/mL, corrected for finasteride would be approximately 3.46 ng/mL, which remains in appropriate range. MRI prostate shows no suspicious lesions. His recent cystoscopy confirms lateral lobe hypertrophy with a median lobe component.

Problem #2: Left adrenal myelolipoma (10 cm)
Large left adrenal mass (10 cm) consistent with myelolipoma that has grown slowly over 20 years. Tumor board on 3/12/2025 reviewed the case and recommended continued surveillance given radiographic appearance and lack of symptoms. Adrenal labs are normal. Most recent CT urogram from 5/1/2025 shows stable appearance.

Problem #3: Right breast mass
Newly identified 2 cm enhancing right breast mass on CT urogram, concerning for malignancy. The patient has been referred to medical oncology for evaluation and management.

PLAN:

1. Continue tamsulosin 0.4mg daily and finasteride 5mg daily for BPH management. Given stable symptoms without progression, patient is satisfied with current medical therapy and declines surgical intervention at this time.

2. Recommend moving furosemide dosing to morning rather than evening to potentially reduce nocturia frequency.

3. Continue surveillance of left adrenal myelolipoma. Will repeat adrenal CT in 12 months (August 2026).

4. Follow up with medical oncology regarding right breast mass. Confirm that patient has completed necessary appointments and testing.

5. Follow-up in urology clinic in 6 months (February 2026) or sooner if symptoms worsen.

6. Advised patient to report any gross hematuria, urinary retention, or other concerning symptoms promptly.

7. Continue use of sildenafil 100mg as needed for ED.
